play.title:
The third Part of Henry the Sixt,
with the death of the Duke of
YORKE.

persona.persname: Lewis the Eleventh, King of France
A Son That Has Killed His Father
A Father That Has Killed His Son

scene.stagedir: Enter Plantagenet, Edward, Richard, Norfolke, Mountague, Warwicke, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Warwicke.
speech.line: I Wonder how the King eſcap’d our hands?

speech.speaker: Pl.
speech.line: While we purſu’d the Horſmen of ý North,
He ſlyly ſtole away, and leﬅ his men:
Whereat the great Lord of Northumberland,
Whoſe Warlike eares could neuer brooke retreat,
Chear’d vp the drouping Army, and himſelfe.
Lord Clifford and Lord Stafford all a-breſt
Charg’d our maine Battailes Front: and breaking in,
Were by the Swords of common Souldiers ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Lord Staffords Father, Duke of Buckingham,
Is either ſlaine or wounded dangerous.
I cleﬅ his Beauer with a down-right blow:
That this is true (Father) behold his blood.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And Brother, here’s the Earle of Wiltſhires blood,
Whom I encountred as the Battels ioyn’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Speake thou for me, and tell them what I did.

speech.speaker: Plan.
speech.line: Richard hath beſt deſeru’d of all my ſonnes:
But is your Grace dead, my Lord of Somerſet?

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: Such hope haue all the line of Iohn of Gaunt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thus do I hope to ſhake King Henries head.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And ſo dœ I, viorious Prince of Yorke.
Before I ſee thee ſeated in that Throne,
Which now the Houſe of Lancaſter vſurpes,
I vow by Heauen, theſe eyes ſhall neuer cloſe.
This is the Pallace of the fearefull King,
And this the Regall Seat: poſſeſſe it Yorke,
For this is thine, and not King Henries Heires.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Aſſiſt me then, ſweet Warwick, and I will,
For hither we haue broken in by force.

speech.speaker: Norf.
speech.line: Wee’le all aſſiſt you: he that ﬂyes, ſhall dye.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Thankes gentle Norfolke, ſtay by me my Lords,
And Souldiers ſtay and lodge by me this Night.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And when the King comes, offer him no violence,
Vnleſſe he ſeeke to thruſt you out perforce.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: The Queene this day here holds her Parliament,
But little thinkes we ſhall be of her counſaile,
By words or blowes here let vs winne our right.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Arm’d as we are, let’s ſtay within this Houſe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: The bloody Parliament ſhall this be call’d,
Vnleſſe Plantagenet, Duke of Yorke, be King,
And baſhfull Henry depos’d, whoſe Cowardize
Hath made vs by-words to our enemies.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Then leaue me not, my Lords be reſolute,
I meane to take poſſeſſion of my Right.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Neither the King, nor he that loues him beſt,
The prowdeſt hee that holds vp Lancaſter,
Dares ſtirre a Wing, if Warwick ſhake his Bells.
Ile plant Plantagenet, root him vp who dares:
Reſolue thee Richard, clayme the Engliſh Crowne.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter King Henry, Clifford, Northumberland, Weſtmerland, Exeter, and the reſt.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: My Lords, looke where the ſturdie Rebell ſits,
Euen in the Chayre of State: belike he meanes,
Backt by the power of Warwicke, that falſe Peere,
To aſpire vnto the Crowne, and reigne as King.
Earle of Northumberland, he ſlew thy Father,
And thine, Lord Clifford, & you both haue vow’d reuenge
On him, his ſonnes, his fauorites, and his friends.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: If I be not, Heauens be reueng’d on me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: The hope thereof, makes Clifford mourne in
Steele.

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: What, ſhall we ſuffer this? lets pluck him down,
My heart for anger burnes, I cannot brooke it.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Be patient, gentle Earle of Weſtmerland.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Patience is for Poultroones, ſuch as he:
He durſt not ſit there, had your Father liu’d.
My gracious Lord, here in the Parliament
Let vs aſſayle the Family of Yorke.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Well haſt thou ſpoken, Couſin be it ſo.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Ah, know you not the Citie fauours them,
And they haue troupes of Souldiers at their beck?

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: But when the Duke is ſlaine, they’le quickly
ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Farre be the thought of this from Henries heart,
To make a Shambles of the Parliament Houſe.
Couſin of Exeter, frownes, words, and threats,
Shall be the Warre that Henry meanes to vſe.
Thou faious Duke of Yorke deſcend my Throne,
And kneele for grace and mercie at my feet,
I am thy Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I am thine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: For ſhame come downe, he made thee Duke of
Yorke.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: It was my Inheritance, as the Earledome was.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Thy Father was a Traytor to the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Exeter thou art a Traytor to the Crowne,
In following this vſurping Henry.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Whom ſhould hee follow, but his naturall
King?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: True Clifford, that’s Richard Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And ſhall I ſtand, and thou ſit in my Throne?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: It muſt and ſhall be ſo, content thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Be Duke of Lancaſter, let him be King.

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: He is both King, and Duke of Lancaſter,
And that the Lord of Weſtmerland ſhall maintaine.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And Warwick ſhall diſproue it. You forget,
That we are thoſe which chas’d you from the ﬁeld,
And ſlew your Fathers, and with Colours ſpread
Marcht through the Citie to the Pallace Gates.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Yes Warwicke, I remember it to my griefe,
And by his Soule, thou and thy Houſe ſhall rue it.

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: Plantagenet, of thee and theſe thy Sonnes,
Thy Kinſmen, and thy Friends, Ile haue more liues
Then drops of bloud were in my Fathers Veines.

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: Vrge it no more, leſt that in ſtead of words,
I ſend thee, Warwicke, ſuch a Meſſenger,
As ſhall reuenge his death, before I ſtirre.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Poore Clifford, how I ſcorne his worthleſſe
Threats.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Will you we ſhew our Title to the Crowne?
If not, our Swords ſhall pleade it in the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: What Title haſt thou Traytor to the Crowne?
My Father was as thou art, Duke of Yorke,
Thy Grandfather Roger Mortimer, Earle of March.
I am the Sonne of Henry the Fiﬅ,
Who made the Dolphin and the French to ſtoupe,
And ſeiz’d vpon their Townes and Prouinces.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Talke not of France, ſith thou haſt loſt it all.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: The Lord Proteor loſt it, and not I:
When I was crown’d, I was but nine moneths old.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You are old enough now,
And yet me thinkes you looſe:
Father teare the Crowne from the Vſurpers Head.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Sweet Father dœ ſo, ſet it on your Head.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Good Brother,
As thou lou’ſt and honoreſt Armes,
Let’s ﬁght it out, and not ſtand cauilling thus.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Sound Drummes and Trumpets, and the
King will ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Sonnes peace.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Peace thou, and giue King Henry leaue to
ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Plantagenet ſhal ſpeake ﬁrſt: Heare him Lords,
And be you ſilent and attentiue too,
For he that interrupts him, ſhall not liue.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Think’ſt thou, that I will leaue my Kingly Throne,
Wherein my Grandſire and my Father ſat?
No: ﬁrſt ſhall Warre vnpeople this my Realme;
I, and their Colours oﬅen borne in France,
And now in England, to our hearts great ſorrow,
Shall be my Winding-ſheet. Why faint you Lords?
My Title’s good, and better farre then his.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Proue it Henry, and thou ſhalt be King.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Henry the Fourth by Conqueſt got the Crowne.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: ’Twas by Rebellion againſt his King.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: I know not what to ſay, my Titles weake:
Tell me, may not a King adopt an Heire?

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: What then?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And if he may, then am I lawfull King:
For Richard, in the view of many Lords,
Reſign’d the Crowne to Henry the Fourth,
Whoſe Heire my Father was, and I am his.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: He roſe againſt him, being his Soueraigne,
And made him to reſigne his Crowne perforce.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Suppoſe, my Lords, he did it vnconſtrayn’d,
Thinke you ’twere preiudiciall to his Crowne?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: No: for he could not ſo reſigne his Crowne,
But that the next Heire ſhould ſucceed and reigne.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Art thou againſt vs, Duke of Exeter?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: His is the right, and therefore pardon me.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Why whiſper you, my Lords, and anſwer not?

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: My Conſcience tells me he is lawfull King.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: All will reuolt from me, and turne to him.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Plantagenet, for all the Clayme thou lay’ſt,
Thinke not, that Henry ſhall be ſo depos’d.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Depos’d he ſhall be, in deſpight of all.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Thou art deceiu’d:
’Tis not thy Southerne power
Of Eſſex, Norfolke, Suffolke, nor of Kent,
Which makes thee thus preſumptuous and prowd,
Can ſet the Duke vp in deſpight of me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: King Henry, be thy Title right or wrong,
Lord Clifford vowes to ﬁght in thy defence:
May that ground gape, and ſwallow me aliue,
Where I ſhall kneele to him that ſlew my Father.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Oh Clifford, how thy words reuiue my heart.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Henry of Lancaſter, reſigne thy Crowne:
What mutter you, or what conſpire you Lords?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Dœ right vnto this Princely Duke of Yorke,
Or I will ﬁll the Houſe with armed men,
And ouer the Chayre of State, where now he ſits,
Write vp his Title with vſurping blood.

scene.stagedir: He ſtampes with his foot, and the Souldiers ſhew themſelues.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: My Lord of Warwick, heare but one word,
Let me for this my life time reigne as King.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Conﬁrme the Crowne to me and to mine Heires,
And thou ſhalt reigne in quiet while thou liu’ſt.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: I am content: Richard Plantagenet
Enioy the Kingdome aﬅer my deceaſe.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: What wrong is this vnto the Prince, your
Sonne?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What good is this to England, and himſelfe?

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: Baſe, fearefull, and deſpayring Henry.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: How haſt thou iniur’d both thy ſelfe and vs?

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: I cannot ſtay to heare theſe Articles.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Nor I.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Come Couſin, let vs tell the Queene theſe
Newes.

speech.speaker: Weſtm.
speech.line: Farwell faint-hearted and degenerate King,
In whoſe cold blood no ſparke of Honor bides.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Be thou a prey vnto the Houſe of Yorke,
And dye in Bands, for this vnmanly deed.

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: In dreadfull Warre may’ſt thou be ouercome,
Or liue in peace abandon’d and deſpis’d.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Turne this way Henry, and regard them not.

speech.speaker: Exeter.
speech.line: They ſeeke reuenge, and therefore will not
yeeld.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Ah Exeter.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why ſhould you ſigh, my Lord?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Not for my ſelfe Lord Warwick, but my Sonne,
Whom I vnnaturally ſhall diſ-inherite.
But be it as it may: I here entayle
The Crowne to thee and to thine Heires for euer,
Conditionally, that heere thou take an Oath,
To ceaſe this Ciuill Warre: and whil’ſt I liue,
To honor me as thy King, and Soueraigne:
And neyther by Treaſon nor Hoſtilitie,
To ſeeke to put me downe, and reigne thy ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: This Oath I willingly take, and will performe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Long liue King Henry: Plantagenet embrace
him.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And long liue thou, and theſe thy forward
Sonnes.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Now Yorke and Lancaſter are reconcil’d.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Accurſt be he that ſeekes to make them fœs.

speech.speaker: Plant.
speech.line: Farewell my gracious Lord, Ile to my Caſtle.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And Ile keepe London with my Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Norf.
speech.line: And I to Norfolke with my followers.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And I vnto the Sea, from whence I came.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: And I with griefe and ſorrow to the Court.

speech.speaker: Exeter.
speech.line: Heere comes the Queene,
Whoſe Lookes bewray her anger:
Ile ſteale away.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Exeter ſo will I.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Nay, gœ not from me, I will follow thee.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Be patient gentle Queene, and I will ſtay.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Who can be patient in ſuch extreames?
Ah wretched man, would I had dy’de a Maid?
And neuer ſeene thee, neuer borne thee Sonne,
Seeing thou haſt prou’d ſo vnnaturall a Father.
Hath he deſeru’d to looſe his Birth-right thus?
Hadſt thou but lou’d him halfe ſo well as I,
Or felt that paine which I did for him once,
Or nouriſht him, as I did with my blood;
Thou would’ſt haue leﬅ thy deareſt heart-blood there,
Rather then haue made that ſauage Duke thine Heire,
And diſ-inherited thine onely Sonne.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Father, you cannot diſ-inherite me:
If you be King, why ſhould not I ſucceede?

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Pardon me Margaret, pardon me ſweet Sonne,
The Earle of Warwick and the Duke enforc’t me.

speech.speaker: Quee.
speech.line: Enforc’t thee? Art thou King, and wilt be forc’t?
I ſhame to heare thee ſpeake: ah timorous Wretch,
Thou haſt vndone thy ſelfe, thy Sonne, and me,
And giu’n vnto the Houſe of Yorke ſuch head,
As thou ſhalt reigne but by their ſufferance.
To entayle him and his Heires vnto the Crowne,
What is it, but to make thy Sepulcher,
And creepe into it farre before thy time?
Warwick is Chancelor, and the Lord of Callice,
Sterne Falconbridge commands the Narrow Seas,
The Duke is made Proteor of the Realme,
And yet ſhalt thou be ſafe? Such ſafetie ﬁndes
The trembling Lambe, inuironned with Wolues.
Had I beene there, which am a ſilly Woman,
The Souldiers ſhould haue toſs’d me on their Pikes,
Before I would haue granted to that A.
But thou preferr’ſt thy Life, before thine Honor.
And ſeeing thou do’ſt, I here diuorce my ſelfe,
Both from thy Table Henry, and thy Bed,
Vntill that A of Parliament be repeal’d,
Whereby my Sonne is diſ-inherited.
The Northerne Lords, that haue forſworne thy Colours,
Will follow mine, if once they ſee them ſpread:
And ſpread they ſhall be, to thy foule diſgrace,
And vtter ruine of the Houſe of Yorke.
Thus dœ I leaue thee: Come Sonne, let’s away,
Our Army is ready; come, wee’le aﬅer them.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Stay gentle Margaret, and heare me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Thou haſt ſpoke too much already: get thee
gone.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Gentle Sonne Edward, thou wilt ſtay me?

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: I, to be murther’d by his Enemies.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: When I returne with viorie to the ﬁeld,
Ile ſee your Grace: till then, Ile follow her.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Come Sonne away, we may not linger thus.

speech.speaker: Henry.
speech.line: Poore Queene,
How loue to me, and to her Sonne,
Hath made her breake out into termes of Rage.
Reueng’d may ſhe be on that hatefull Duke,
Whoſe haughtie ſpirit, winged with deſire,
Will coſt my Crowne, and like an emptie Eagle,
Tyre on the ﬂeſh of me, and of my Sonne.
The loſſe of thoſe three Lords torments my heart:
Ile write vnto them, and entreat them faire;
Come Couſin, you ſhall be the Meſſenger.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: And I, I hope, ſhall reconcile them all.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Richard, Edward, and Mountague.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Brother, though I bee youngeſt, giue mee
leaue.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: No, I can better play the Orator.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: But I haue reaſons ſtrong and forceable.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Why how now Sonnes, and Brother, at a ſtrife?
What is your Quarrell? how began it ﬁrſt?

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: No Quarrell, but a ſlight Contention.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: About what?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: About that which concernes your Grace and vs,
The Crowne of England, Father, which is yours.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Mine Boy? not till King Henry be dead.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Your Right depends not on his life, or death.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Now you are Heire, therefore enioy it now:
By giuing the Houſe of Lancaſter leaue to breathe,
It will out-runne you, Father, in the end.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I tooke an Oath, that hee ſhould quietly
reigne.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: But for a Kingdome any Oath may be broken:
I would breake a thouſand Oathes, to reigne one yeere.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: No: God forbid your Grace ſhould be for —
ſworne.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I ſhall be, if I clayme by open Warre.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Ile proue the contrary, if you’le heare mee
ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Thou canſt not, Sonne: it is impoſſible.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: An Oath is of no moment, being not tooke
Before a true and lawfull Magiſtrate,
That hath authoritie ouer him that ſweares.
Henry had none, but did vſurpe the place.
Then ſeeing ’twas he that made you to depoſe,
Your Oath, my Lord, is vaine and friuolous.
Therefore to Armes: and Father dœ but thinke,
How ſweet a thing it is to weare a Crowne,
Within whoſe Circuit is Elizium,
And all that Pœts faine of Bliſſe and Ioy.
Why dœ we linger thus? I cannot reſt,
Vntill the White Roſe that I weare, be dy’de
Euen in the luke-warme blood of Henries heart.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Richard ynough: I will be King, or dye.
Brother, thou ſhalt to London preſently,
And whet on Warwick to this Enterpriſe.
Thou Richard ſhalt to the Duke of Norfolke,
And tell him priuily of our intent.
You Edward ſhall vnto my Lord Cobham,
With whom the Kentiſhmen will willingly riſe.
In them I truſt: for they are Souldiors,
Wittie, courteous, liberall, full of ſpirit.
While you are thus imploy’d, what reſteth more?
But that I ſeeke occaſion how to riſe,
And yet the King not priuie to my Driﬅ,
Nor any of the Houſe of Lancaſter.
But ſtay, what Newes? Why comm’ſt thou in ſuch
poſte?

speech.speaker: Gabriel.
speech.line: The Queene,
With all the Northerne Earles and Lords,
Intend here to beſiege you in your Caſtle.
She is hard by, with twentie thouſand men:
And therefore fortiﬁe your Hold, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I, with my Sword.
What? think’ſt thou, that we feare them?
Edward and Richard, you ſhall ſtay with me,
My Brother Mountague ſhall poſte to London.
Let Noble Warwicke, Cobham, and the reſt,
Whom we haue leﬅ Proteors of the King,
With powrefull Pollicie ſtrengthen themſelues,
And truſt not ſimple Henry, nor his Oathes.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Brother, I gœ: Ile winne them, feare it not.
And thus moſt humbly I dœ take my leaue.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Sir Iohn, and Sir Hugh Mortimer, mine Vnckles,
You are come to Sandall in a happie houre.
The Armie of the Queene meane to beſiege vs.

speech.speaker: Iohn.
speech.line: Shee ſhall not neede, wee’le meete her in the
ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: What, with ﬁue thouſand men?

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: I, with ﬁue hundred, Father, for a neede.
A Woman’s generall: what ſhould we feare?

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: I heare their Drummes:
Let’s ſet our men in order,
And iſſue forth, and bid them Battaile ſtraight.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Fiue men to twentie: though the oddes be great,
I doubt not, Vnckle, of our Viorie.
Many a Battaile haue I wonne in France,
When as the Enemie hath beene tenne to one:
Why ſhould I not now haue the like ſucceſſe?

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Ah, whither ſhall I ﬂye, to ſcape their hands?
Ah Tutor, looke where bloody Clifford comes.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Chaplaine away, thy Prieſthood ſaues thy life.
As for the Brat of this accurſed Duke,
Whoſe Father ſlew my Father, he ſhall dye.

speech.speaker: Tutor.
speech.line: And I, my Lord, will beare him company.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Souldiers, away with him.

speech.speaker: Tutor.
speech.line: Ah Clifford, murther not this innocent Child,
Leaſt thou be hated both of God and Man.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: How now? is he dead alreadie?
Or is it feare, that makes him cloſe his eyes?
Ile open them.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: So looks the pent-vp Lyon o’re the Wretch,
That trembles vnder his deuouring Pawes:
And ſo he walkes, inſulting o’re his Prey,
And ſo he comes, to rend his Limbes aſunder.
Ah gentle Clifford, kill me with thy Sword,
And not with ſuch a cruell threatning Looke.
Sweet Clifford heare me ſpeake, before I dye:
I am too meane a ſubie for thy Wrath,
Be thou reueng’d on men, and let me liue.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: In vaine thou ſpeak’ſt, poore Boy:
My Fathers blood hath ſtopt the paſſage
Where thy words ſhould enter.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Then let my Fathers blood open it againe,
He is a man, and Clifford cope with him.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Had I thy Brethren here, their liues and thine
Were not reuenge ſufﬁcient for me:
No, if I digg’d vp thy fore-fathers Graues,
And hung their rotten Cofﬁns vp in Chaynes,
It could not ſlake mine ire, nor eaſe my heart.
The ſight of any of the Houſe of Yorke,
Is as a furie to torment my Soule:
And till I root out their accurſed Line,
And leaue not one aliue, I liue in Hell.
Therefore —

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: Oh let me pray, before I take my death:
To thee I pray; ſweet Clifford pitty me.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Such pitty as my Rapiers point affords.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: I neuer did thee harme: why wilt thou ſlay
me?

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Thy Father hath.

speech.speaker: Rutland.
speech.line: But ’twas ere I was borne.
Thou haſt one Sonne, for his ſake pitty me,
Leaſt in reuenge thereof, ſith God is iuſt,
He be as miſerably ſlaine as I.
Ah, let me liue in Priſon all my dayes,
And when I giue occaſion of offence,
Then let me dye, for now thou haſt no cauſe.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: No cauſe? thy Father ſlew my Father: there —
fore dye.

line.emph: Dij faciant laudis ſumma ſit iſta tuæ.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Plantagenet, I come Plantagenet:
And this thy Sonnes blood cleauing to my Blade,
Shall ruſt vpon my Weapon, till thy blood
Congeal’d with this, dœ make me wipe off both.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter Richard, Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: The Army of the Queene hath got the ﬁeld:
My Vnckles both are ſlaine, in reſcuing me;
And all my followers, to the eager fœ
Turne back, and ﬂye, like Ships before the Winde,
Or Lambes purſu’d by hunger-ſtarued Wolues.
My Sonnes, God knowes what hath bechanced them:
But this I know, they haue demean’d themſelues
Like men borne to Renowne, by Life or Death.
Three times did Richard make a Lane to me,
And thrice cry’de, Courage Father, ﬁght it out:
And full as oﬅ came Edward to my ſide,
With Purple Faulchion, painted to the Hilt,
In blood of thoſe that had encountred him:
And when the hardyeſt Warriors did retyre,
Richard cry’de, Charge, and giue no foot of ground,
And cry’de, A Crowne, or elſe a glorious Tombe,
A Scepter, or an Earthly Sepulchre.
With this we charg’d againe: but out alas,
We bodg’d againe, as I haue ſeene a Swan
With bootleſſe labour ſwimme againſt the Tyde,
And ſpend her ſtrength with ouer-matching Waues.
Ah hearke, the fatall followers dœ purſue,
And I am faint, and cannot ﬂye their furie:
And were I ſtrong, I would not ſhunne their furie.
The Sands are numbred, that makes vp my Life,
Here muſt I ſtay, and here my Life muſt end.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Queene, Clifford, Northumberland, the young Prince, and Souldiers.

speech.line: Come bloody Clifford, rough Northumberland,
I dare your quenchleſſe furie to more rage:
I am your Butt, and I abide your Shot.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Yeeld to our mercy, proud Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I, to ſuch mercy, as his ruthleſſe Arme
With downe-right payment, ſhew’d vnto my Father.
Now Phæton hath tumbled from his Carre,
And made an Euening at the Noone-tide Prick.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: My aſhes, as the Phœnix, may bring forth
A Bird, that will reuenge vpon you all:
And in that hope, I throw mine eyes to Heauen,
Scorning what ere you can afﬂi me with.
Why come you not? what, multitudes, and feare?

speech.speaker: Cliff.
speech.line: So Cowards ﬁght, when they can ﬂye no further,
So Doues dœ peck the Faulcons piercing Tallons,
So deſperate Theeues, all hopeleſſe of their Liues,
Breathe out Inueiues ’gainſt the Ofﬁcers.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Oh Clifford, but bethinke thee once againe,
And in thy thought ore-run my former time:
And if thou canſt, for bluſhing, view this face,
And bite thy tongue, that ſlanders him with Cowardice,
Whoſe frowne hath made thee faint and ﬂye ere this.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I will not bandie with thee word for word,
But buckler with thee blowes twice two for one.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Hold valiant Clifford, for a thouſand cauſes
I would prolong a while the Traytors Life:
Wrath makes him deafe; ſpeake thou Northumberland.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Hold Clifford, dœ not honor him ſo much,
To prick thy ﬁnger, though to wound his heart.
What valour were it, when a Curre doth grinne,
For one to thruſt his Hand betweene his Teeth,
When he might ſpurne him with his Foot away?
It is Warres prize, to take all Vantages,
And tenne to one, is no impeach of Valour.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: I, I, ſo ſtriues the Woodcocke with the
Gynne.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: So doth the Connie ſtruggle in the
Net.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: So triumph Theeues vpon their conquer’d Booty,
So True men yeeld with Robbers, ſo o’re-matcht.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: What would your Grace haue done vnto
him now?

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Braue Warriors, Clifford and Northumberland,
Come make him ſtand vpon this Mole-hill here,
That raught at Mountaines with out-ſtretched Armes,
Yet parted but the ſhadow with his Hand.
What, was it you that would be Englands King?
Was’t you that reuell’d in our Parliament,
And made a Preachment of your high Deſcent?
Where are your Meſſe of Sonnes, to back you now?
The wanton Edward, and the luſtie George?
And where’s that valiant Crook-back Prodigie,
Dickie, your Boy, that with his grumbling voyce
Was wont to cheare his Dad in Mutinies?
Or with the reſt, where is your Darling, Rutland?
Looke Yorke, I ſtayn’d this Napkin with the blood
That valiant Clifford, with his Rapiers point,
Made iſſue from the Boſome of the Boy:
And if thine eyes can water for his death,
I giue thee this to drie thy Cheekes withall.
Alas poore Yorke, but that I hate thee deadly,
I ſhould lament thy miſerable ſtate.
I prythee grieue, to make me merry, Yorke.
What, hath thy ﬁerie heart ſo parcht thine entrayles,
That not a Teare can fall, for Rutlands death?
Why art thou patient, man? thou ſhould’ſt be mad:
And I, to make thee mad, dœ mock thee thus.
Stampe, raue, and fret, that I may ſing and dance.
Thou would’ſt be fee’d, I ſee, to make me ſport:
Yorke cannot ſpeake, vnleſſe he weare a Crowne.
A Crowne for Yorke; and Lords, bow lowe to him:
Hold you his hands, whileſt I dœ ſet it on.
I marry Sir, now lookes he like a King:
I, this is he that tooke King Henries Chaire,
And this is he was his adopted Heire.
But how is it, that great Plantagenet
Is crown’d ſo ſoone, and broke his ſolemne Oath?
As I bethinke me, you ſhould not be King,
Till our King Henry had ſhooke hands with Death.
And will you pale your head in Henries Glory,
And rob his Temples of the Diademe,
Now in his Life, againſt your holy Oath?
Oh ’tis a fault too too vnpardonable.
Off with the Crowne; and with the Crowne, his Head,
And whileſt we breathe, take time to dœ him dead.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: That is my Ofﬁce, for my Fathers ſake.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, let’s heare the Orizons hee
makes.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Shee-Wolfe of France,
But worſe then Wolues of France,
Whoſe Tongue more poyſons then the Adders Tooth:
How ill-beſeeming is it in thy Sex,
To triumph like an Amazonian Trull,
Vpon their Wœs, whom Fortune captiuates?
But that thy Face is Vizard-like, vnchanging,
Made impudent with vſe of euill deedes.
I would aſſay, prowd Queene, to make thee bluſh.
To tell thee whence thou cam’ſt, of whom deriu’d,
Were ſhame enough, to ſhame thee,
Wert thou not ſhameleſſe.
Thy Father beares the type of King of Naples,
Of both the Sicils, and Ieruſalem,
Yet not ſo wealthie as an Engliſh Yeoman.
Hath that poore Monarch taught thee to inſult?
It needes not, nor it bootes thee not, prowd Queene,
Vnleſſe the Adage muſt be verify’d,
That Beggers mounted, runne their Horſe to death.
’Tis Beautie that doth oﬅ make Women prowd,
But God he knowes, thy ſhare thereof is ſmall.
’Tis Vertue, that doth make them moſt admir’d,
The contrary, doth make thee wondred at.
’Tis Gouernment that makes them ſeeme Diuine,
The want thereof, makes thee abhominable.
Thou art as oppoſite to euery good,
As the Antipodes are vnto vs,
Or as the South to the Septentrion.
Oh Tygres Heart, wrapt in a Womans Hide,
How could’ſt thou drayne the Life-blood of the Child,
To bid the Father wipe his eyes withall,
And yet be ſeene to beare a Womans face?
Women are ſoﬅ, milde, pittifull, and ﬂexible;
Thou, ſterne, obdurate, ﬂintie, rough, remorſeleſſe.
Bidſt thou me rage? why now thou haſt thy wiſh.
Would’ſt haue me weepe? why now thou haſt thy will.
For raging Wind blowes vp inceſſant ſhowers,
And when the Rage allayes, the Raine begins.
Theſe Teares are my ſweet Rutlands Obſequies,
And euery drop cryes vengeance for his death,
’Gainſt thee fell Clifford, and thee falſe French-woman.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Beſhrew me, but his paſſions moues me ſo,
That hardly can I check my eyes from Teares.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: That Face of his,
The hungry Caniballs would not haue toucht,
Would not haue ſtayn’d with blood:
But you are more inhumane, more inexorable,
Oh, tenne times more then Tygers of Hyrcania.
See, ruthleſſe Queene, a hapleſſe Fathers Teares:
This Cloth thou dipd’ſt in blood of my ſweet Boy,
And I with Teares dœ waſh the blood away.
Keepe thou the Napkin, and gœ boaſt of this,
And if thou tell’ſt the heauie ſtorie right,
Vpon my Soule, the hearers will ſhed Teares:
Yea, euen my Fœs will ſhed faſt-falling Teares,
And ſay, Alas, it was a pittious deed.
There, take the Crowne, and with the Crowne, my Curſe,
And in thy need, ſuch comfort come to thee,
As now I reape at thy too cruell hand.
Hard-hearted Clifford, take me from the World,
My Soule to Heauen, my Blood vpon your Heads.

speech.speaker: Northumb.
speech.line: Had he been ſlaughter-man to all my Kinne,
I ſhould not for my Life but weepe with him,
To ſee how inly Sorrow gripes his Soule.

speech.speaker: Queen.
speech.line: What, weeping ripe, my Lord Northumberland?
Thinke but vpon the wrong he did vs all,
And that will quickly drie thy melting Teares.

speech.speaker: Clifford.
speech.line: Heere’s for my Oath, heere’s for my Fathers
Death.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: And heere’s to right our gentle-hearted
King.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Open thy Gate of Mercy, gracious God,
My Soule ﬂyes through theſe wounds, to ſeeke out thee.

speech.speaker: Queene.
speech.line: Off with his Head, and ſet it on Yorke Gates,
So Yorke may ouer-looke the Towne of Yorke.

scene.stagedir: A March. Enter Edward, Richard, and their power.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: I wonder how our Princely Father ſcap’t:
Or whether he be ſcap’t away, or no,
From Cliffords and Northumberlands purſuit?
Had he been ta’ne, we ſhould haue heard the newes;
Had he beene ſlaine, we ſhould haue heard the newes:
Or had he ſcap’t, me thinkes we ſhould haue heard
The happy tidings of his good eſcape.
How fares my Brother? why is he ſo ſad?

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: I cannot ioy, vntill I be reſolu’d
Where our right valiant Father is become.
I ſaw him in the Battaile range about,
And watcht him how he ſingled Clifford forth.
Me thought he bore him in the thickeſt troupe,
As doth a Lyon in a Heard of Neat,
Or as a Beare encompaſs’d round with Dogges:
Who hauing pincht a few, and made them cry,
The reſt ſtand all aloofe, and barke at him.
So far’d our Father with his Enemies,
So ﬂed his Enemies my Warlike Father:
Me thinkes ’tis prize enough to be his Sonne.
See how the Morning opes her golden Gates,
And takes her farwell of the glorious Sunne.
How well reſembles it the prime of Youth,
Trimm’d like a Yonker, prauncing to his Loue?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Dazle mine eyes, or dœ I ſee three Sunnes?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Three glorious Sunnes, each one a perfe Sunne,
Not ſeperated with the racking Clouds,
But ſeuer’d in a pale cleare-ſhining Skye.
See, ſee, they ioyne, embrace, and ſeeme to kiſſe,
As if they vow’d ſome League inuiolable.
Now are they but one Lampe, one Light, one Sunne:
In this, the Heauen ﬁgures ſome euent.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: ’Tis wondrous ſtrange,
The like yet neuer heard of.
I thinke it cites vs (Brother) to the ﬁeld,
That wee, the Sonnes of braue Plantagenet,
Each one alreadie blazing by our meedes,
Should notwithſtanding ioyne our Lights together,
And ouer-ſhine the Earth, as this the World.
What ere it bodes, hence-forward will I beare
Vpon my Targuet three faire ſhining Sunnes.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Nay, beare three Daughters:
By your leaue, I ſpeake it,
You loue the Breeder better then the Male.
But what art thou, whoſe heauie Lookes fore-tell
Some dreadfull ſtory hanging on thy Tongue?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Ah, one that was a wofull looker on,
When as the Noble Duke of Yorke was ſlaine,
Your Princely Father, and my louing Lord.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Oh ſpeake no more, for I haue heard too
much.

speech.speaker: Richard.
speech.line: Say how he dy’de, for I will heare it all.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Enuironed he was with many fœs,
And ſtood againſt them, as the hope of Troy
Againſt the Greekes, that would haue entred Troy.
But Hercules himſelfe muſt yeeld to oddes:
And many ſtroakes, though with a little Axe,
Hewes downe and fells the hardeſt-tymber’d Oake.
By many hands your Father was ſubdu’d,
But onely ſlaught’red by the irefull Arme
Of vn-relenting Clifford, and the Queene:
Who crown’d the gracious Duke in high deſpight,
Laugh’d in his face: and when with griefe he wept,
The ruthleſſe Queene gaue him, to dry his Cheekes,
A Napkin, ſteeped in the harmeleſſe blood
Of ſweet young Rutland, by rough Clifford ſlaine:
And aﬅer many ſcornes, many foule taunts,
They tooke his Head, and on the Gates of Yorke
They ſet the ſame, and there it doth remaine,
The ſaddeſt ſpeacle that ere I view’d.

speech.speaker: Edward.
speech.line: Sweet Duke of Yorke, our Prop to leane vpon,
Now thou art gone, wee haue no Staffe, no Stay.
Oh Clifford, boyſt’rous Clifford thou haſt ſlaine
The ﬂowre of Europe, for his Cheualrie,
And trecherouſly haſt thou vanquiſht him,
For hand to hand he would haue vanquiſht thee.
Now my Soules Pallace is become a Priſon:
Ah, would ſhe breake from hence, that this my body
Might in the ground be cloſed vp in reſt:
For neuer henceforth ſhall I ioy againe:
Neuer, oh neuer ſhall I ſee more ioy.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I cannot weepe: for all my bodies moyſture
Scarſe ſerues to quench my Furnace-burning hart:
Nor can my tongue vnloade my hearts great burthen,
For ſelfe-ſame winde that I ſhould ſpeake withall,
Is kindling coales that ﬁres all my breſt,
And burnes me vp with ﬂames, that tears would quench.
To weepe, is to make leſſe the depth of greefe:
Teares then for Babes; Blowes, and Reuenge for mee.
Richard, I beare thy name, Ile venge thy death,
Or dye renowned by attempting it.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: His name that valiant Duke hath leﬅ with thee:
His Dukedome, and his Chaire with me is leﬅ.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay, if thou be that Princely Eagles Bird,
Shew thy deſcent by gazing ’gainſt the Sunne:
For Chaire and Dukedome, Throne and Kingdome ſay,
Either that is thine, or elſe thou wer’t not his.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Warwicke, Marqueſſe Mountacute, and their Army.

speech.speaker: Warwick.
speech.line: How now faire Lords? What faire? What
newes abroad?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Great Lord of Warwicke, if we ſhould recompt
Our balefull newes, and at each words deliuerance
Stab Poniards in our ﬂeſh, till all were told,
The words would adde more anguiſh then the wounds.
O valiant Lord, the Duke of Yorke is ſlaine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: O Warwicke, Warwicke, that Plantagenet
Which held thee deerely, as his Soules Redemption,
Is by the ſterne Lord Clifford done to death.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Ten dayes ago, I drown’d theſe newes in teares.
And now to adde more meaſure to your wœs,
I come to tell you things ſith then befalne.
Aﬅer the bloody Fray at Wakeﬁeld fought,
Where your braue Father breath’d his lateſt gaſpe,
Tydings, as ſwiﬅly as the Poſtes could runne,
Were brought me of your Loſſe, and his Depart.
I then in London, keeper of the King,
Muſter’d my Soldiers, gathered ﬂockes of Friends,
Marcht toward S. Albons, to intercept the Queene,
Bearing the King in my behalfe along:
For by my Scouts, I was aduertiſed
That ſhe was comming with a full intent
To daſh our late Decree in Parliament,
Touching King Henries Oath, and your Succeſsion:
Short Tale to make, we at S. Albons met,
Our Battailes ioyn’d, and both ſides ﬁercely fought:
But whether ’twas the coldneſſe of the King,
Who look’d full gently on his warlike Queene,
That robb’d my Soldiers of their heated Spleene.
Or whether ’twas report of her ſucceſſe,
Or more then common feare of Cliffords Rigour,
Who thunders to his Captiues, Blood and Death,
I cannot iudge: but to conclude with truth,
Their Weapons like to Lightning, came and went:
Our Souldiers like the Night-Owles lazie ﬂight,
Or like a lazie Threſher with a Flaile,
Fell gently downe, as if they ſtrucke their Friends.
I cheer’d them vp with iuſtice of our Cauſe,
With promiſe of high pay, and great Rewards:
But all in vaine, they had no heart to ﬁght,
And we (in them) no hope to win the day,
So that we ﬂed: the King vnto the Queene,
Lord George, your Brother, Norfolke, and my Selfe,
In haſte, poſt haſte, are come to ioyne with you:
For in the Marches heere we heard you were,
Making another Head, to ﬁght againe.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Where is the Duke of Norfolke, gentle Warwick?
And when came George from Burgundy to England?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Some ſix miles off the Duke is with the Soldiers,
And for your Brother he was lately ſent
From your kinde Aunt Dutcheſſe of Burgundie,
With ayde of Souldiers to this needfull Warre.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: ’Twas oddes belike, when valiant Warwick ﬂed;
Oﬅ haue I heard his praiſes in Purſuite,
But ne’re till now, his Scandall of Retire.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Nor now my Scandall Richard, doſt thou heare:
For thou ſhalt know this ſtrong right hand of mine,
Can plucke the Diadem from faint Henries head,
And wring the awefull Scepter from his Fiſt,
Were he as famous, and as bold in Warre,
As he is fam’d for Mildneſſe, Peace, and Prayer.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I know it well Lord Warwick, blame me not,
’Tis loue I beare thy glories make me ſpeake:
But in this troublous time, what’s to be done?
Shall we go throw away our Coates of Steele,
And wrap our bodies in blacke mourning Gownes,
Numb’ring our Aue-Maries with our Beads?
Or ſhall we on the Helmets of our Fœs
Tell our Deuotion with reuengefull Armes?
If for the laſt, ſay I, and to it Lords.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Why therefore Warwick came to ſeek you out,
And therefore comes my Brother Mountague:
Attend me Lords, the proud inſulting Queene,
With Clifford, and the haught Northumberland,
And of their Feather, many mœ proud Birds,
Haue wrought the eaſie-melting King, like Wax.
He ſwore conſent to your Succeſſion,
His Oath enrolled in the Parliament.
And now to London all the crew are gone,
To fruſtrate both his Oath, and what beſide
May make againſt the houſe of Lancaſter.
Their power (I thinke) is thirty thouſand ſtrong:
Now, if the helpe of Norfolke, and my ſelfe,
With all the Friends that thou braue Earle of March,
Among’ſt the louing Welſhmen can’ſt procure,
Will but amount to ﬁue and twenty thouſand,
Why Via, to London will we march,
And once againe, beſtride our foaming Steeds,
And once againe cry Charge vpon our Fœs,
But neuer once againe turne backe and ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, now me thinks I heare great Warwick ſpeak;
Ne’re may he liue to ſee a Sun-ſhine day,
That cries Retire, if Warwicke bid him ſtay.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Lord Warwicke, on thy ſhoulder will I leane,
And when thou failſt (as God forbid the houre)
Muſt Edward fall, which perill heauen forfend.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: No longer Earle of March, but Duke of Yorke:
The next degree, is Englands Royall Throne:
For King of England ſhalt thou be proclaim’d
In euery Burrough as we paſſe along,
And he that throwes not vp his cap for ioy,
Shall for the Fault make forfeit of his head.
King Edward, valiant Richard Mountague:
Stay we no longer, dreaming of Renowne.
But ſound the Trumpets, and about our Taske.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then Clifford, were thy heart as hard as Steele,
As thou haſt ſhewne it ﬂintie by thy deeds,
I come to pierce it, or to giue thee mine.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Then ſtrike vp Drums, God and S. George for vs.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How now? what newes?

speech.speaker: Mes.
speech.line: The Duke of Norfolke ſends you word by me,
The Queene is comming with a puiſſant Hoaſt,
And craues your company, for ſpeedy counſell.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Why then it ſorts, braue Warriors, let’s away.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter the King, the Queene, Clifford, Northum and Yong Prince, with Drumme and Trumpettes.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Welcome my Lord, to this braue town of Yorke,
Yonders the head of that Arch-enemy,
That ſought to be incompaſt with your Crowne.
Doth not the obie cheere your heart, my Lord.

speech.speaker: K.
speech.line: I, as the rockes cheare them that feare their wrack,
To ſee this ſight, it irkes my very ſoule:
With-hold reuenge (deere God) ’tis not my fault,
Nor wittingly haue I infring’d my Vow.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My gracious Liege, this too much lenity
And harmfull pitty muſt be layd aſide:
To whom do Lyons caſt their gentle Lookes?
Not to the Beaſt, that would vſurpe their Den.
Whoſe hand is that the Forreſt Beare doth licke?
Not his that ſpoyles her yong before her face.
Who ſcapes the lurking Serpents mortall ſting?
Not he that ſets his foot vpon her backe.
The ſmalleſt Worme will turne, being troden on,
And Doues will pecke in ſafegard of their Brood.
Ambitious Yorke, did leuell at thy Crowne,
Thou ſmiling, while he knit his angry browes.
He but a Duke, would haue his Sonne a King,
And raiſe his iſſue like a louing Sire.
Thou being a King, bleſt with a goodly ſonne,
Did’ſt yeeld conſent to diſinherit him:
Which argued thee a moſt vnlouing Father.
Vnreaſonable Creatures feed their young,
And though mans face be fearefull to their eyes,
Yet in proteion of their tender ones,
Who hath not ſeene them euen with thoſe wings,
Which ſometime they haue vs’d with fearfull ﬂight,
Make warre with him that climb’d vnto their neſt,
Offering their owne liues in their yongs defence?
For ſhame, my Liege, make them your Preſident:
Were it not pitty that this goodly Boy
Should looſe his Birth-right by his Fathers fault,
And long heereaﬅer ſay vnto his childe,
What my great Grandfather, and Grandſire got,
My careleſſe Father fondly gaue away.
Ah, what a ſhame were this? Looke on the Boy,
And let his manly face, which promiſeth
Succeſſefull Fortune ſteele thy melting heart,
To hold thine owne, and leaue thine owne with him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Full well hath Clifford plaid the Orator,
Inferring arguments of mighty force:
But Clifford tell me, did’ſt thou neuer heare,
That things ill got, had euer bad ſucceſſe.
And happy alwayes was it for that Sonne,
Whoſe Father for his hoording went to hell:
Ile leaue my Sonne my Vertuous deeds behinde,
And would my Father had leﬅ me no more:
For all the reſt is held at ſuch a Rate,
As brings a thouſand fold more care to keepe,
Then in poſſeſſion any iot of pleaſure.
Ah Coſin Yorke, would thy beſt Friends did know,
How it doth greeue me that thy head is heere.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: My Lord cheere vp your ſpirits, our fœs are nye,
And this ſoﬅ courage makes your Followers faint:
You promiſt Knighthood to our forward ſonne,
Vnſheath your ſword, and dub him preſently.
Edward, kneele downe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Edward Plantagenet, ariſe a Knight,
And learne this Leſſon; Draw thy Sword in right.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: My gracious Father, by your Kingly leaue,
Ile draw it as Apparant to the Crowne,
And in that quarrell, vſe it to the death.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Why that is ſpoken like a toward Prince.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Royall Commanders, be in readineſſe,
For with a Band of thirty thouſand men,
Comes Warwicke backing of the Duke of Yorke,
And in the Townes as they do march along,
Proclaimes him King, and many ﬂye to him,
Darraigne your battell, for they are at hand.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I would your Highneſſe would depart the ﬁeld,
The Queene hath beſt ſucceſſe when you are abſent.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I good my Lord, and leaue vs to our Fortune.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why, that’s my fortune too, therefore Ile ſtay.

speech.speaker: North.
speech.line: Be it with reſolution then to ﬁght.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: My Royall Father, cheere theſe Noble Lords,
And hearten thoſe that ﬁght in your defence:
Vnſheath your Sword, good Father: Cry S. George.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Edward, Warwicke, Richard, Clarence, Norfolke, Mountague, and Soldiers.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now periur’d Henry, wilt thou kneel for grace?
And ſet thy Diadem vpon my head?
Or bide the mortall Fortune of the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Go rate thy Minions, proud inſulting Boy,
Becomes it thee to be thus bold in termes,
Before thy Soueraigne, and thy lawfull King?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: I am his King, and he ſhould bow his knee:
I was adopted Heire by his conſent.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Since when, his Oath is broke: for as I heare,
You that are King, though he do weare the Crowne,
Haue caus’d him by new A of Parliament,
To blot out me, and put his owne Sonne in.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: And reaſon too,
Who ſhould ſucceede the Father, but the Sonne.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Are you there Butcher? O, I cannot ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I Crooke-back, here I ſtand to anſwer thee,
Or any he, the proudeſt of thy ſort.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: ’Twas you that kill’d yong Rutland, was it not?

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I, and old Yorke, and yet not ſatisﬁed.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: For Gods ſake Lords giue ſignall to the ﬁght.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: What ſay’ſt thou Henry,
Wilt thou yeeld the Crowne?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Why how now long-tongu’d Warwicke, dare you ſpeak?
When you and I, met at S. Albons laſt,
Your legges did better ſeruice then your hands.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then ’twas my turne to ﬂy, and now ’tis thine:

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: You ſaid ſo much before, and yet you ﬂed.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: ’Twas not your valor Clifford droue me thence.

speech.speaker: Nor.
speech.line: No, nor your manhood that durſt make you ſtay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Northumberland, I hold thee reuerently,
Breake off the parley, for ſcarſe I can refraine
The execution of my big-ſwolne heart
Vpon that Clifford, that cruell Child-killer.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: I ſlew thy Father, cal’ſt thou him a Child?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I like a Daſtard, and a treacherous Coward,
As thou didd’ſt kill our tender Brother Rutland,
But ere Sunſet, Ile make thee curſe the deed.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Haue done with words (my Lords) and heare
me ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Deﬁe them then, or els hold cloſe thy lips.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I prythee giue no limits to my Tongue,
I am a King, and priuiledg’d to ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: My Liege, the wound that bred this meeting here,
Cannot be cur’d by Words, therefore be ſtill.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Then Executioner vnſheath thy ſword:
By him that made vs all, I am reſolu’d,
That Cliffords Manhood, lyes vpon his tongue.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Say Henry, ſhall I haue my right, or no:
A thouſand men haue broke their Faſts to day,
That ne’re ſhall dine, vnleſſe thou yeeld the Crowne.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: If thou deny, their Blood vpon thy head,
For Yorke in iuſtice put’s his Armour on.

speech.speaker: Pr.Ed.
speech.line: If that be right, which Warwick ſaies is right,
There is no vvrong, but euery thing is right.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Who euer got thee, there thy Mother ſtands,
For well I vvot, thou haſt thy Mothers tongue.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: But thou art neyther like thy Sire nor Damme,
But like a foule miſhapen Stygmaticke,
Mark’d by the Deſtinies to be auoided,
As venome Toades, or Lizards dreadfull ſtings.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Iron of Naples, hid with Engliſh gilt,
Whoſe Father beares the Title of a King,
(As if a Channell ſhould be call’d the Sea)
Sham’ſt thou not, knowing whence thou art extraught,
To let thy tongue dete thy baſe-borne heart.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: A wiſpe of ſtraw were worth a thouſand Crowns,
To make this ſhameleſſe Callet know her ſelfe:
Helen of Greece was fayrer farre then thou,
Although thy Husband may be Menelaus;
And ne’re was Agamemnons Brother wrong’d
By that falſe Woman, as this King by thee.
His Father reuel’d in the heart of France,
And tam’d the King, and made the Dolphin ſtoope:
And had he match’d according to his State,
He might haue kept that glory to this day.
But when he tooke a begger to his bed,
And grac’d thy poore Sire with his Bridall day,
Euen then that Sun-ſhine brew’d a ſhowre for him,
That waſht his Fathers fortunes forth of France,
And heap’d ſedition on his Crowne at home:
For what hath broach’d this tumult but thy Pride?
Had’ſt thou bene meeke, our Title ſtill had ſlept,
And we in pitty of the Gentle King,
Had ſlipt our Claime, vntill another Age.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: But when we ſaw, our Sunſhine made thy Spring,
And that thy Summer bred vs no increaſe,
We ſet the Axe to thy vſurping Roote:
And though the edge hath ſomething hit our ſelues,
Yet know thou, ſince we haue begun to ſtrike,
Wee’l neuer leaue, till we haue hewne thee downe,
Or bath’d thy growing, with our heated bloods.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: And in this reſolution, I deﬁe thee,
Not willing any longer Conference,
Since thou denied’ſt the gentle King to ſpeake.
Sound Trumpets, let our bloody Colours waue,
And either Viorie, or elſe a Graue.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Stay Edward.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: No wrangling Woman, wee’l no longer ſtay,
Theſe words will coſt ten thouſand liues this day.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Fore-ſpent with Toile, as Runners with a Race,
I lay me downe a little while to breath:
For ſtrokes receiu’d, and many blowes repaid,
Haue robb’d my ſtrong knit ſinewes of their ſtrength,
And ſpight of ſpight, needs muſt I reſt a-while.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Smile gentle heauen, or ſtrike vngentle death,
For this world frownes, and Edwards Sunne is clowded.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How now my Lord, what happe? what hope of
good?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Our hap is loſſe, our hope but ſad diſpaire,
Our rankes are broke, and ruine followes vs.
What counſaile giue you? whether ſhall we ﬂye?

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Bootleſſe is ﬂight, they follow vs with Wings,
And weake we are, and cannot ſhun purſuite.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, why haſtӳ withdrawn thy ſelfe?
Thy Brothers blood the thirſty earth hath drunk,
Broach’d with the Steely point of Cliffords Launce:
And in the very pangs of death, he cryde,
Like to a diſmall Clangor heard from farre,
Warwicke, reuenge; Brother, reuenge my death.
So vnderneath the belly of their Steeds,
That ſtain’d their Fetlockes in his ſmoaking blood,
The Noble Gentleman gaue vp the ghoſt.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then let the earth be drunken with our blood:
Ile kill my Horſe, becauſe I will not ﬂye:
Why ſtand we like ſoﬅ-hearted women heere,
Wayling our loſſes, whiles the Fœ doth Rage,
And looke vpon, as if the Tragedie
Were plaid in ieſt, by counterfetting Aors.
Heere on my knee, I vow to God aboue,
Ile neuer pawſe againe, neuer ſtand ſtill,
Till either death hath clos’d theſe eyes of mine,
Or Fortune giuen me meaſure of Reuenge.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Oh Warwicke, I do bend my knee with thine,
And in this vow do chaine my ſoule to thine:
And ere my knee riſe from the Earths cold face,
I throw my hands, mine eyes, my heart to thee,
Thou ſetter vp, and plucker downe of Kings:
Beſeeching thee (if with thy will it ſtands)
That to my Fœs this body muſt be prey,
Yet that thy brazen gates of heauen may ope,
And giue ſweet paſſage to my ſinfull ſoule.
Now Lords, take leaue vntill we meete againe,
Where ere it be, in heauen, or in earth.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother,
Giue me thy hand, and gentle Warwicke,
Let me imbrace thee in my weary armes:
I that did neuer weepe, now melt with wo,
That Winter ſhould cut off our Spring-time ſo.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Away, away:
Once more ſweet Lords farwell.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Yet let vs altogether to our Troopes,
And giue them leaue to ﬂye, that will not ſtay:
And call them Pillars that will ſtand to vs:
And if we thriue, promiſe them ſuch rewards
As Viors weare at the Olympian Games.
This may plant courage in their quailing breaſts,
For yet is hope of Life and Viory:
Foreſlow no longer, make we hence amaine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now Clifford, I haue ſingled thee alone,
Suppoſe this arme is for the Duke of Yorke,
And this for Rutland, both bound to reuenge,
Wer’t thou inuiron’d with a Brazen wall.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Now Richard, I am with thee heere alone,
This is the hand that ſtabb’d thy Father Yorke,
And this the hand, that ſlew thy Brother Rutland,
And here’s the heart, that triumphs in their death,
And cheeres theſe hands, that ſlew thy Sire and Brother,
To execute the like vpon thy ſelfe,
And ſo haue at thee.

scene.stagedir: They Fight, Warwicke comes, Clifford ﬂies.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay Warwicke, ſingle out ſome other Chace,
For I my ſelfe will hunt this Wolfe to death.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: This battell fares like to the mornings Warre,
When dying clouds contend, with growing light,
What time the Shepheard blowing of his nailes,
Can neither call it perfe day, nor night.
Now ſwayes it this way, like a Mighty Sea,
Forc’d by the Tide, to combat with the Winde:
Now ſwayes it that way, like the ſelfe-ſame Sea,
Forc’d to retyre by furie of the Winde.
Sometime, the Flood preuailes; and than the Winde:
Now, one the better: then, another beſt;
Both tugging to be Viors, breſt to breſt:
Yet neither Conqueror, nor Conquered.
So is the equall poiſe of this fell Warre.
Heere on this Mole-hill will I ſit me downe,
To whom God will, there be the Viorie:
For Margaret my Queene, and Clifford too
Haue chid me from the Battell: Swearing both,
They proſper beſt of all when I am thence.
Would I were dead, if Gods good will were ſo;
For what is in this world, but Greefe and Wœ.
Oh God! me thinkes it were a happy life,
To be no better then a homely Swaine,
To ſit vpon a hill, as I do now,
To carue out Dialls queintly, point by point,
Thereby to ſee the Minutes how they runne:
How many makes the Houre full compleate,
How many Houres brings about the Day,
How many Dayes will ﬁniſh vp the Yeare,
How many Yeares, a Mortall man may liue.
When this is knowne, then to diuide the Times:
So many Houres, muſt I tend my Flocke;
So many Houres, muſt I take my Reſt:
So many Houres, muſt I Contemplate:
So many Houres, muſt I Sport my ſelfe:
So many Dayes, my Ewes haue bene with yong:
So many weekes, ere the poore Fooles will Eane:
So many yeares, ere I ſhall ſheere the Fleece:
So Minutes, Houres, Dayes, Monthes, and Yeares,
Paſt ouer to the end they were created,
Would bring white haires, vnto a Quiet graue.
Ah! what a life were this? How ſweet?how louely?
Giues not the Hawthorne buſh a ſweeter ſhade
To Shepheards looking on their ſilly Sheepe,
Then doth a rich Imbroider’d Canopie
To Kings, that feare their Subies treacherie?
Oh yes, it doth; a thouſand fold it doth.
And to conclude, the Shepherds homely Curds,
His cold thinne drinke out of his Leather Bottle,
His wonted ſleepe, vnder a freſh trees ſhade,
All which ſecure, and ſweetly he enioyes,
Is farre beyond a Princes Delicates:
His Viands ſparkling in a Golden Cup,
His bodie couched in a curious bed,
When Care, Miſtruſt, and Treaſon waits on him.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter a Sonne that hath kill’d his Father, at one doore: and a Father that hath kill’d his Sonne at another doore.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Ill blowes the winde that proﬁts no body,
This man whom hand to hand I ſlew in ﬁght,
May be poſſeſſed with ſome ſtore of Crownes,
And I that (haply) take them from him now,
May yet (ere night) yeeld both my Life and them
To ſome man elſe, as this dead man doth me.
Who’s this? Oh God! It is my Fathers face,
Whom in this Conﬂi, I (vnwares) haue kill’d:
Oh heauy times! begetting ſuch Euents.
From London, by the King was I preſt forth,
My Father being the Earle of Warwickes man,
Came on the part of Yorke, preſt by his Maſter:
And I, who at his hands receiu’d my life,
Haue by my hands, of Life bereaued him.
Pardon me God, I knew not what I did:
And pardon Father, for I knew not thee.
My Teares ſhall wipe away theſe bloody markes:
And no more words, till they haue ﬂow’d their ﬁll.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: O pitteous ſpeacle! O bloody Times!
Whiles Lyons Warre, and battaile for their Dennes,
Poore harmleſſe Lambes abide their enmity.
Weepe wretched man: Ile ayde thee Teare for Teare,
And let our hearts and eyes, like Ciuill Warre,
Be blinde with teares, and break ore-charg’d with griefe

scene.stagedir: Enter Father, bearing of his Sonne.

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: Thou that ſo ſtoutly hath reſiſted me,
Giue me thy Gold, if thou haſt any Gold:
For I haue bought it with an hundred blowes.
But let me ſee: Is this our Fœ-mans face?
Ah, no, no, no, it is mine onely Sonne.
Ah Boy, if any life be leﬅ in thee,
Throw vp thine eye: ſee, ſee, what ſhowres ariſe,
Blowne with the windie Tempeſt of my heart,
Vpon thy wounds, that killes mine Eye, and Heart.
O pitty God, this miſerable Age!
What Stragems? how fell? how Butcherly?
Erreoneous, mutinous, and vnnaturall,
This deadly quarrell daily doth beget?
O Boy! thy Father gaue thee life too ſoone,
And hath bereﬅ thee of thy life too late.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Wo aboue wo: greefe, more thē common greefe
O that my death would ſtay theſe ruthfull deeds:
O pitty, pitty, gentle heauen pitty:
The Red Roſe and the White are on his face,
The fatall Colours of our ſtriuing Houſes:
The one, his purple Blood right well reſembles,
The other his pale Cheekes (me thinkes) preſenteth:
Wither one Roſe, and let the other ﬂouriſh:
If you contend, a thouſand liues muſt wither.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: How will my Mother, for a Fathers death
Take on with me, and ne’re be ſatisﬁ’d?

speech.speaker: Fa.
speech.line: How will my Wife, for ſlaughter of my Sonne,
Shed ſeas of Teares, and ne’re be ſatisﬁ’d?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How will the Country, for theſe woful chances,
Miſ-thinke the King, and not be ſatisﬁed?

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Was euer ſonne, ſo rew’d a Fathers death?

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: Was euer Father ſo bemoan’d his Sonne?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Was euer King ſo greeu’d for Subies wœ?
Much is your ſorrow; Mine, ten times ſo much.

speech.speaker: Son.
speech.line: Ile beare thee hence, where I may weepe my ﬁll.

speech.speaker: Fath.
speech.line: Theſe armes of mine ſhall be thy winding ſheet:
My heart (ſweet Boy) ſhall be thy Sepulcher,
For from my heart, thine Image ne’re ſhall go.
My ſighing breſt, ſhall be thy Funerall bell;
And ſo obſequious will thy Father be,
Men for the loſſe of thee, hauing no more,
As Priam was for all his Valiant Sonnes,
Ile beare thee hence, and let them ﬁght that will,
For I haue murthered where I ſhould not kill.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Sad-hearted-men, much ouergone with Care;
Heere ſits a King, more wofull then you are.

scene.stagedir: Alarums. Excurſions. Enter the Queen, the Prince, and Exeter.

speech.speaker: Prin.
speech.line: Fly Father, ﬂye: for all your Friends are ﬂed.
And Warwicke rages like a chafed Bull:
Away, for death doth hold vs in purſuite.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Mount you my Lord, towards Barwicke poſt a —
maine:
Edward and Richard like a brace of Grey-hounds,
Hauing the fearfull ﬂying Hare in ſight,
With ﬁery eyes, ſparkling for very wrath,
And bloody ſteele graſpt in their yrefull hands
Are at our backes, and therefore hence amaine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Away: for vengeance comes along with them.
Nay, ſtay not to expoſtulate, make ſpeed,
Or elſe come aﬅer, Ile away before.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Nay take me with thee, good ſweet Exeter:
Not that I feare to ſtay, but loue to go
Whether the Queene intends. Forward, away.

scene.stagedir: A lowd alarum. Enter Clifford Wounded.

speech.speaker: Clif.
speech.line: Heere burnes my Candle out: I, heere it dies,
Which whiles it laſted, gaue King Henry light.
O Lancaſter! I feare thy ouerthrow,
More then my Bodies parting with my Soule:
My Loue and Feare, glew’d many Friends to thee,
And now I fall. Thy tough Commixtures melts,
Impairing Henry, ſtrength’ning miſproud Yorke;
And whether ﬂye the Gnats, but to the Sunne?
And who ſhines now, but Henries Enemies?
O Phœbus! had’ſt thou neuer giuen conſent,
That Phæton ſhould checke thy ﬁery Steeds,
Thy burning Carre neuer had ſcorch’d the earth.
And Henry, had’ſt thou ſway’d as Kings ſhould do,
Or as thy Father, and his Father did,
Giuing no ground vnto the houſe of Yorke,
They neuer then had ſprung like Sommer Flyes:
I, and ten thouſand in this luckleſſe Realme,
Hed leﬅ no mourning Widdowes for our death,
And thou this day, had’ſt kept thy Chaire in peace.
For what doth cherriſh Weeds, but gentle ayre?
And what makes Robbers bold, but too much lenity?
Bootleſſe are Plaints, and Cureleſſe are my Wounds:
No way to ﬂye, no ſtrength to hold out ﬂight:
The Fœ is mercileſſe, and will not pitty:
For at their hands I haue deſeru’d no pitty.
The ayre hath got into my deadly Wounds,
And much effuſe of blood, doth make me faint:
Come Yorke, and Richard, Warwicke, and the reſt,
I ſtab’d your Fathers boſomes; Split my breſt.

scene.stagedir: Alarum & Retreat. Enter Edward, Warwicke, Richard, and Soldiers, Montague, & Clarence.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Now breath we Lords, good fortune bids vs pauſe,
And ſmooth the frownes of War, with peacefull lookes:
Some Troopes purſue the bloody-minded Queene,
That led calme Henry, though he were a King,
As doth a Saile, ﬁll’d with a fretting Guſt
Command an Argoſie to ſtemme the Waues.
But thinke you (Lords) that Clifford ﬂed with them?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: No, ’tis impoſsible he ſhould eſcape:
(For though before his face I ſpeake the words)
Your Brother Richard markt him for the Graue.
And whereſœre he is, hee’s ſurely dead.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Whoſe ſoule is that which takes hir heauy leaue?
A deadly grone, like life and deaths departing.
See who it is.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: And now the Battailes ended,
If Friend or Fœ, let him be gently vſed.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Reuoke that doome of mercy, for ’tis Clifford,
Who not contented that he lopp’d the Branch
In hewing Rutland, when his leaues put forth,
But ſet his murth’ring knife vnto the Roote,
From whence that tender ſpray did ſweetly ſpring,
I meane our Princely Father, Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: From off the gates of Yorke, fetch down ý head,
Your Fathers head, which Clifford placed there:
In ſtead whereof, let this ſupply the roome,
Meaſure for meaſure, muſt be anſwered.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Bring forth that fatall Schreechowle to our houſe,
That nothing ſung but death, to vs and ours:
Now death ſhall ſtop his diſmall threatning ſound,
And his ill-boading tongue, no more ſhall ſpeake.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I thinke his vnderſtanding is bereﬅ:
Speake Clifford, doſt thou know who ſpeakes to thee?
Darke cloudy death ore-ſhades his beames of life,
And he nor ſees, nor heares vs, what we ſay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: O would he did, and ſo (perhaps) he doth,
’Tis but his policy to counterfet,
Becauſe he would auoid ſuch bitter taunts
Which in the time of death he gaue our Father.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: If ſo thou think’ſt,
Vex him with eager Words.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Clifford, aske mercy, and obtaine no grace.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Clifford, repent in bootleſſe penitence.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Clifford, deuiſe excuſes for thy faults.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: While we deuiſe fell Tortures for thy faults.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thou didd’ſt loue Yorke, and I am ſon to Yorke.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thou pittied’ſt Rutland, I will pitty thee.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Where’s Captaine Margaret, to fence you now?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: They mocke thee Clifford,
Sweare as thou was’t wont.

speech.speaker: Ric.
speech.line: What, not an Oath? Nay then the world go’s hard
When Clifford cannot ſpare his Friends an oath:
I know by that he’s dead, and by my Soule,
If this right hand would buy two houres life,
That I (in all deſpight) might rayle at him,
This hand ſhould chop it off: & with the iſſuing Blood
Stiﬂe the Villaine, whoſe vnſlanched thirſt
Yorke, and yong Rutland could not ſatisﬁe

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I, but he’s dead. Of with the Traitors head,
And reare it in the place your Fathers ſtands.
And now to London with Triumphant march,
There to be crowned Englands Royall King:
From whence, ſhall Warwicke cut the Sea to France,
And aske the Ladie Bona for thy Queene:
So ſhalt thou ſinow both theſe Lands together,
And hauing France thy Friend, thou ſhalt not dread
The ſcattred Fœ, that hopes to riſe againe:
For though they cannot greatly ſting to hurt,
Yet looke to haue them buz to offend thine eares:
Firſt, will I ſee the Coronation,
And then to Britanny Ile croſſe the Sea,
To effe this marriage, ſo it pleaſe my Lord.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Euen as thou wilt ſweet Warwicke, let it bee:
For in thy ſhoulder do I builde my Seate;
And neuer will I vndertake the thing
Wherein thy counſaile and conſent is wanting:
Richard, I will create thee Duke of Glouceſter,
And George of Clarence; Warwicke as our Selfe,
Shall do, and vndo as him pleaſeth beſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Let me be Duke of Clarence, George of Gloſter,
For Gloſters Dukedome is too ominous.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Tut, that’s a fooliſh obſeruation:
Richard, be Duke of Gloſter: Now to London,
To ſee theſe Honors in poſſeſſion.

scene.stagedir: Enter Sinklo, and Humfrey, with Croſſe-bowes in their hands.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Vnder this thicke growne brake, wee’l ſhrowd our ſelues:
For through this Laund anon the Deere will come,
And in this couert will we make our Stand,
Culling the principall of all the Deere.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Ile ſtay aboue the hill, ſo both may ſhoot.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: That cannot be, the noiſe of thy Croſſe-bow
Will ſcarre the Heard, and ſo my ſhoot is loſt:
Heere ſtand we both, and ayme we at the beſt:
And for the time ſhall not ſeeme tedious,
Ile tell thee what befell me on a day,
In this ſelfe-place, where now we meane to ſtand.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Heere comes a man, let’s ſtay till he be paſt:

scene.stagedir: Enter the King with a Prayer booke.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: From Scotland am I ſtolne euen of pure loue,
To greet mine owne Land with my wiſhfull ſight:
No Harry, Harry, ’tis no Land of thine,
Thy place is ﬁll’d, thy Scepter wrung from thee,
Thy Balme waſht off, wherewith thou was Annointed:
No bending knee will call thee Cæſar now,
No humble ſuters preaſe to ſpeake for right:
No, not a man comes for redreſſe of thee:
For how can I helpe them, and not my ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: I, heere’s a Deere, whoſe skin’s a Keepers Fee:
This is the quondam King; Let’s ſeize vpon him.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Let me embrace the ſower Aduerſaries,
For Wiſe men ſay, it is the wiſeſt courſe.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Why linger we? Let vs lay hands vpon him.

speech.speaker: Sink.
speech.line: Forbeare a-while, wee’l heare a little more.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: My Queene and Son are gone to France for aid:
And (as I heare) the great Commanding Warwicke
I: thither gone, to craue the French Kings Siſter
To wife for Edward. If this newes be true,
Poore Queene, and Sonne, your labour is but loſt:
For Warwicke is a ſubtle Orator:
And Lewis a Prince ſoone wonne with mouing words:
By this account then, Margaret may winne him,
For ſhe’s a woman to be pittied much:
Her ſighes will make a batt’ry in his breſt,
Her teares will pierce into a Marble heart:
The Tyger will be milde, whiles ſhe doth mourne;
And Nero will be tainted with remorſe,
To heare and ſee her plaints, her Briniſh Teares.
I, but ſhee’s come to begge, Warwicke to giue:
Shee on his leﬅ ſide, crauing ayde for Henrie;
He on his right, asking a wife for Edward.
Shee Weepes, and ſayes, her Henry is depos’d:
He Smiles, and ſayes, his Edward is inſtaul’d;
That ſhe (poore Wretch) for greefe can ſpeake no more:
Whiles Warwicke tels his Title, ſmooths the Wrong,
Inferreth arguments of mighty ſtrength,
And in concluſion winnes the King from her,
With promiſe of his Siſter, and what elſe,
To ſtrengthen and ſupport King Edwards place.
O Margaret, thus ’twill be, and thou (poore ſoule)
Art then forſaken, as thou went’ſt forlorne.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Say, what art thou talk’ſt of Kings & Queens?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: More then I ſeeme, and leſſe then I was born to:
A man at leaſt, for leſſe I ſhould not be:
And men may talke of Kings, and why not I?

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: I, but thou talk’ſt, as if thou wer’t a King.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why ſo I am (in Minde) and that’s enough.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: But if thou be a King, where is thy Crowne?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Crowne is in my heart, not on my head:
Not deck’d with Diamonds, and Indian ſtones:
Nor to be ſeene: my Crowne, is call’d Content,
A Crowne it is, that ſildome Kings enioy.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Well, if you be a King crown’d with Content,
Your Crowne Content, and you, muſt be contented
To go along with vs. For (as we thinke)
You are the king King Edward hath depos’d:
And we his ſubies, ſworne in all Allegeance,
Will apprehend you, as his Enemie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But did you neuer ſweare, and breake an Oath.

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: No, neuer ſuch an Oath, nor will not now.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Where did you dwell when I was K. of England?

speech.speaker: Hum.
speech.line: Heere in this Country, where we now remaine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I was annointed King at nine monthes old,
My Father, and my Grandfather were Kings:
And you were ſworne true Subies vnto me:
And tell me then, haue you not broke your Oathes?

speech.speaker: Sin.
speech.line: No, for we were Subies, but while you wer king

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why? Am I dead? Do I not breath a Man?
Ah ſimple men, you know not what you ſweare:
Looke, as I blow this Feather from my Face,
And as the Ayre blowes it to me againe,
Obeying with my winde when I do blow,
And yeelding to another, when it blowes,
Commanded alwayes by the greater guſt:
Such is the lightneſſe of you, common men.
But do not breake your Oathes, for of that ſinne,
My milde intreatie ſhall not make you guiltie.
Go where you will, the king ſhall be commanded,
And be you kings, command, and Ile obey.

speech.speaker: Sinklo.
speech.line: We are true Subies to the king,
King Edward.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: So would you be againe to Henrie,
If he were ſeated as king Edward is.

speech.speaker: Sinklo.
speech.line: We charge you in Gods name & the Kings,
To go with vs vnto the Ofﬁcers.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: In Gods name lead, your Kings name be obeyd,
And what God will, that let your King performe,
And what he will, I humbly yeeld vnto.

scene.stagedir: Enter K. Edward, Gloſter, Clarence, Lady Gray.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brother of Gloſter, at S. Albons ﬁeld
This Ladyes Husband, Sir Richard Grey, was ſlaine,
His Land then ſeiz’d on by the Conqueror,
Her ſuit is now, to repoſſeſſe thoſe Lands,
Which wee in Iuſtice cannot well deny,
Becauſe in Quarrell of the Houſe of Yorke,
The worthy Gentleman did loſe his Life.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Your Highneſſe ſhall dœ well to graunt her ſuit:
It were diſhonor to deny it her.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: It were no leſſe, but yet Ile make a pawſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Yea, is it ſo:
I ſee the Lady hath a thing to graunt,
Before the King will graunt her humble ſuit.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Hee knowes the Game, how true hee keepes
the winde?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Silence.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Widow, we will conſider of your ſuit,
And come ſome other time to know our minde.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Right gracious Lord, I cannot brooke delay:
May it pleaſe your Highneſſe to reſolue me now,
And what your pleaſure is, ſhall ſatisﬁe me.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I Widow? then Ile warrant you all your Lands,
And if what pleaſes him, ſhall pleaſure you:
Fight cloſer, or good faith you’le catch a Blow.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I feare her not, vnleſſe ſhe chance to fall.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: God forbid that, for hee’le take vantages.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: How many Children haſt thou, Widow? tell
me.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I thinke he meanes to begge a Child of her.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Nay then whip me: hee’le rather giue her two.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Three, my moſt gracious Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: You ſhall haue foure, if you’le be rul’d by him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: ’Twere pittie they ſhould loſe their Fathers
Lands.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Be pittifull, dread Lord, and graunt it then.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Lords giue vs leaue, Ile trye this Widowes
wit.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, good leaue haue you, for you will haue leaue,
Till Youth take leaue, and leaue you to the Crutch.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now tell me, Madame, dœ you loue your
Children?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: I, full as dearely as I loue my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And would you not dœ much to dœ them
good?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: To dœ them good, I would ſuſtayne ſome
harme.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Then get your Husbands Lands, to dœ them
good.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Therefore I came vnto your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ile tell you how theſe Lands are to be got.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: So ſhall you bind me to your Highneſſe ſeruice.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What ſeruice wilt thou dœ me, if I giue them?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: What you command, that reſts in me to dœ.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But you will take exceptions to my Boone.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: No, gracious Lord, except I cannot dœ it.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, but thou canſt dœ what I meane to aske.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then I will dœ what your Grace com —
mands.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Hee plyes her hard, and much Raine weares the
Marble.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: As red as ﬁre? nay then, her Wax muſt melt.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why ſtoppes my Lord? ſhall I not heare my
Taske?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: An eaſie Taske, ’tis but to loue a King.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: That’s ſoone perform’d, becauſe I am a Subie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then, thy Husbands Lands I freely giue
thee.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: I take my leaue with many thouſand thankes.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Match is made, ſhee ſeales it with a Curſie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But ſtay thee, ’tis the fruits of loue I meane.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: The fruits of Loue, I meane, my louing Liege.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, but I feare me in another ſence.
