What Loue, think’ſt thou, I ſue ſo much to get?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: My loue till death, my humble thanks, my prayers,
That loue which Vertue begges, and Vertue graunts.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No, by my troth, I did not meane ſuch loue.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then you meane not, as I thought you did.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But now you partly may perceiue my minde.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: My minde will neuer graunt what I perceiue
Your Highneſſe aymes at, if I ayme aright.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: To tell thee plaine, I ayme to lye with thee.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: To tell you plaine, I had rather lye in Priſon.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why then thou ſhalt not haue thy Husbands
Lands.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Why then mine Honeſtie ſhall be my Dower,
For by that loſſe, I will not purchaſe them.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Therein thou wrong’ſt thy Children mightily.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Herein your Highneſſe wrongs both them & me:
But mightie Lord, this merry inclination
Accords not with the ſadneſſe of my ſuit:
Pleaſe you diſmiſſe me, eyther with I, or no.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, if thou wilt ſay I to my requeſt:
No, if thou do’ſt ſay No to my demand.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: Then No, my Lord: my ſuit is at an end.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Widow likes him not, ſhee knits her
Browes.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Hee is the blunteſt Woœr in Chriſten —
dome.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Her Looks doth argue her replete with Modeſty,
Her Words doth ſhew her Wit incomparable,
All her perfeions challenge Soueraigntie,
One way, or other, ſhee is for a King,
And ſhee ſhall be my Loue, or elſe my Queene.
Say, that King Edward take thee for his Queene?

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: ’Tis better ſaid then done, my gracious Lord:
I am a ſubie ﬁt to ieaſt withall,
But farre vnﬁt to be a Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sweet Widow, by my State I ſweare to thee,
I ſpeake no more then what my Soule intends,
And that is, to enioy thee for my Loue.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: And that is more then I will yeeld vnto:
I know, I am too meane to be your Queene,
And yet too good to be your Concubine.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: You cauill, Widow, I did meane my Queene.

speech.speaker: Wid.
speech.line: ’Twill grieue your Grace, my Sonnes ſhould call
you Father.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: No more, then when my Daughters
Call thee Mother.
Thou art a Widow, and thou haſt ſome Children,
And by Gods Mother, I being but a Batchelor,
Haue other-ſome. Why, ’tis a happy thing,
To be the Father vnto many Sonnes:
Anſwer no more, for thou ſhalt be my Queene.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Ghoſtly Father now hath done his Shriﬅ.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: When hee was made a Shriuer, ’twas for ſhiﬅ.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Brothers, you muſe what Chat wee two haue
had.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Widow likes it not, for ſhee lookes very
ſad.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: You’ld thinke it ſtrange, if I ſhould marrie
her.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: To who, my Lord?

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why Clarence, to my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That would be tenne dayes wonder at the leaſt.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: That’s a day longer then a Wonder laſts.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: By ſo much is the Wonder in extremes.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Well, ieaſt on Brothers: I can tell you both,
Her ſuit is graunted for her Husbands Lands.

speech.speaker: Nob.
speech.line: My gracious Lord, Henry your Fœ is taken,
And brought your Priſoner to your Pallace Gate.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: See that he be conuey’d vnto the Tower:
And gœ wee Brothers to the man that tooke him,
To queſtion of his apprehenſion.
Widow gœ you along: Lords vſe her honourable.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, Edward will vſe Women honourably:
Would he were waſted, Marrow, Bones, and all,
That from his Loynes no hopefull Branch may ſpring,
To croſſe me from the Golden time I looke for:
And yet, betweene my Soules deſire, and me,
The luſtfull Edwards Title buryed,
Is Clarence, Henry, and his Sonne young Edward,
And all the vnlook’d-for Iſſue of their Bodies,
To take their Roomes, ere I can place my ſelfe:
A cold premeditation for my purpoſe.
Why then I dœ but dreame on Soueraigntie,
Like one that ſtands vpon a Promontorie,
And ſpyes a farre-off ſhore, where hee would tread,
Wiſhing his foot were equall with his eye,
And chides the Sea, that ſunders him from thence,
Saying hee’le lade it dry, to haue his way:
So dœ I wiſh the Crowne, being ſo farre off,
And ſo I chide the meanes that keepes me from it,
And ſo (I ſay) Ile cut the Cauſes off,
Flattering me with impoſſibilities:
My Eyes too quicke, my Heart o’re-weenes too much,
Vnleſſe my Hand and Strength could equall them.
Well, ſay there is no Kingdome then for Richard:
What other Pleaſure can the World affoord?
Ile make my Heauen in a Ladies Lappe,
And decke my Body in gay Ornaments,
And ’witch ſweet Ladies with my Words and Lookes.
Oh miſerable Thought! and more vnlikely,
Then to accompliſh twentie Golden Crownes.
Why Loue forſwore me in my Mothers Wombe:
And for I ſhould not deale in her ſoﬅ Lawes,
Shee did corrupt frayle Nature with ſome Bribe,
To ſhrinke mine Arme vp like a wither’d Shrub,
To make an enuious Mountaine on my Back,
Where ſits Deformitie to mocke my Body;
To ſhape my Legges of an vnequall ſize,
To diſ-proportion me in euery part:
Like to a Chaos, or an vn-lick’d Beare-whelpe,
That carryes no impreſſion like the Damme.
And am I then a man to be belou’d?
Oh monſtrous fault, to harbour ſuch a thought.
Then ſince this Earth affoords no Ioy to me,
But to command, to check, to o’re-beare ſuch,
As are of better Perſon then my ſelfe:
Ile make my Heauen, to dreame vpon the Crowne,
And whiles I liue, t’account this World but Hell,
Vntill my mis-ſhap’d Trunke, that beares this Head,
Be round impaled with a glorious Crowne.
And yet I know not how to get the Crowne,
For many Liues ſtand betweene me and home:
And I, like one loſt in a Thornie Wood,
That rents the Thornes, and is rent with the Thornes,
Seeking a way, and ſtraying from the way,
Not knowing how to ﬁnde the open Ayre,
But toyling deſperately to ﬁnde it out,
Torment my ſelfe, to catch the Engliſh Crowne:
And from that torment I will free my ſelfe,
Or hew my way out with a bloody Axe.
Why I can ſmile, and murther whiles I ſmile,
And cry, Content, to that which grieues my Heart,
And wet my Cheekes with artiﬁciall Teares,
And frame my Face to all occaſions.
Ile drowne more Saylers then the Mermaid ſhall,
Ile ſlay more gazers then the Baſiliske,
Ile play the Orator as well as Neſtor,
Deceiue more ſlyly then Vliſſes could,
And like a Synon, take another Troy.
I can adde Colours to the Camelion,
Change ſhapes with Proteus, for aduantages,
And ſet the murtherous Macheuill to Schoole.
Can I dœ this, and cannot get a Crowne?
Tut, were it farther off, Ile plucke it downe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Lewis the French King, his Sister Bona, his Admirall, call’d Bourbon: Prince Edward, Queene Margaret, and the Earle of Oxford. Lewis ſits, and riſeth vp againe.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Faire Queene of England, worthy Margaret,
Sit downe with vs: it ill beﬁts thy State,
And Birth, that thou ſhould’ſt ſtand, while Lewis doth ſit.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: No, mightie King of France: now Margaret
Muſt ſtrike her ſayle, and learne a while to ſerue,
Where Kings command. I was (I muſt confeſſe)
Great Albions Queene, in former Golden dayes:
But now miſchance hath trod my Title downe,
And with diſ-honor layd me on the ground,
Where I muſt take like Seat vnto my fortune,
And to my humble Seat conforme my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Why ſay, faire Queene, whence ſprings this
deepe deſpaire?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: From ſuch a cauſe, as ﬁlls mine eyes with teares,
And ſtops my tongue, while heart is drown’d in cares.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: What ere it be, be thou ſtill like thy ſelfe,
And ſit thee by our ſide.
Yeeld not thy necke to Fortunes yoake,
But let thy dauntleſſe minde ſtill ride in triumph,
Ouer all miſchance.
Be plaine, Queene Margaret, and tell thy griefe,
It ſhall be eas’d, if France can yeeld reliefe.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Thoſe gracious words
Reuiue my drooping thoughts,
And giue my tongue-ty’d ſorrowes leaue to ſpeake.
Now therefore be it knowne to Noble Lewis,
That Henry, ſole poſſeſſor of my Loue,
Is, of a King, become a baniſht man,
And forc’d to liue in Scotland a Forlorne;
While prowd ambitious Edward, Duke of Yorke,
Vſurpes the Regall Title, and the Seat
Of Englands true anoynted lawfull King.
This is the cauſe that I, poore Margaret,
With this my Sonne, Prince Edward, Henries Heire,
Am come to craue thy iuſt and lawfull ayde:
And if thou faile vs, all our hope is done.
Scotland hath will to helpe, but cannot helpe:
Our People, and our Peeres, are both miſ-led,
Our Treaſure ſeiz’d, our Souldiors put to ﬂight,
And (as thou ſeeſt) our ſelues in heauie plight.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Renowned Queene,
With patience calme the Storme,
While we bethinke a meanes to breake it off.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: The more wee ſtay, the ſtronger growes our
Fœ.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: The more I ſtay, the more Ile ſuccour thee.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: O, but impatience waiteth on true ſorrow.
And ſee where comes the breeder of my ſorrow.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: What’s hee approacheth boldly to our pre —
ſence?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Our Earle of Warwicke, Edwards greateſt
Friend.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Welcome braue Warwicke, what brings thee
to France?

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: I now begins a ſecond Storme to riſe,
For this is hee that moues both Winde and Tyde.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: From worthy Edward, King of Albion,
My Lord and Soueraigne, and thy vowed Friend,
I come (in Kindneſſe, and vnfayned Loue)
Firſt, to dœ greetings to thy Royall Perſon,
And then to craue a League of Amitie:
And laſtly, to conﬁrme that Amitie
With Nuptiall Knot, if thou vouchſafe to graunt
That vertuous Lady Bona, thy faire Siſter,
To Englands King, in lawfull Marriage.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: If that gœ forward, Henries hope is done.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And gracious Madame,
In our Kings behalfe,
I am commanded, with your leaue and fauor,
Humbly to kiſſe your Hand, and with my Tongue
To tell the paſſion of my Soueraignes Heart;
Where Fame, late entring at his heedfull Eares,
Hath plac’d thy Beauties Image, and thy Vertue.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: King Lewis, and Lady Bona, heare me ſpeake,
Before you anſwer Warwicke. His demand
Springs not from Edwards well-meant honeſt Loue,
But from Deceit, bred by Neceſſitie:
For how can Tyrants ſafely gouerne home,
Vnleſſe abroad they purchaſe great allyance?
To proue him Tyrant, this reaſon may ſufﬁce,
That Henry liueth ſtill: but were hee dead,
Yet here Prince Edward ſtands, King Henries Sonne.
Looke therefore Lewis, that by this League and Mariage
Thou draw not on thy Danger, and Dis-honor:
For though Vſurpers ſway the rule a while,
Yet Heau’ns are iuſt, and Time ſuppreſſeth Wrongs.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Iniurious Margaret.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: And why not Queene?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Becauſe thy Father Henry did vſurpe,
And thou no more art Prince, then ſhee is Queene.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Then Warwicke diſanulls great Iohn of Gaunt,
Which did ſubdue the greateſt part of Spaine;
And aﬅer Iohn of Gaunt, Henry the Fourth,
Whoſe Wiſdome was a Mirror to the wiſeſt:
And aﬅer that wiſe Prince, Henry the Fiﬅ,
Who by his Proweſſe conquered all France:
From theſe, our Henry lineally deſcends.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Oxford, how haps it in this ſmooth diſcourſe,
You told not, how Henry the Sixt hath loſt
All that, which Henry the Fiﬅ had gotten:
Me thinkes theſe Peeres of France ſhould ſmile at that.
But for the reſt: you tell a Pedigree
Of threeſcore and two yeeres, a ſilly time
To make preſcription for a Kingdomes worth.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Why Warwicke, canſt thou ſpeak againſt thy Liege,
Whom thou obeyd’ſt thirtie and ſix yeeres,
And not bewray thy Treaſon with a Bluſh?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Can Oxford, that did euer fence the right,
Now buckler Falſehood with a Pedigree?
For ſhame leaue Henry, and call Edward King.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Call him my King, by whoſe iniurious doome
My elder Brother, the Lord Aubrey Vere
Was done to death? and more then ſo, my Father,
Euen in the downe-fall of his mellow’d yeeres,
When Nature brought him to the doore of Death?
No Warwicke, no: while Life vpholds this Arme,
This Arme vpholds the Houſe of Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And I the Houſe of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Queene Margaret, Prince Edward, and Oxford,
Vouchſafe at our requeſt, to ſtand aſide,
While I vſe further conference with Warwicke.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Heauens graunt, that Warwickes wordes be —
witch him not.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Now Warwicke, tell me euen vpon thy conſcience
Is Edward your true King? for I were loth
To linke with him, that were not lawfull choſen.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Thereon I pawne my Credit, and mine Ho —
nor.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: But is hee gracious in the Peoples eye?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: The more, that Henry was vnfortunate.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Then further: all diſſembling ſet aſide,
Tell me for truth, the meaſure of his Loue
Vnto our Siſter Bona.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Such it ſeemes,
As may beſeeme a Monarch like himſelfe.
My ſelfe haue oﬅen heard him ſay, and ſweare,
That this his Loue was an externall Plant,
Whereof the Root was ﬁxt in Vertues ground,
The Leaues and Fruit maintain’d with Beauties Sunne,
Exempt from Enuy, but not from Diſdaine,
Vnleſſe the Lady Bona quit his paine.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Now Siſter, let vs heare your ﬁrme reſolue.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Your graunt, or your denyall, ſhall be mine.
Yet I confeſſe, that oﬅen ere this day,
When I haue heard your Kings deſert recounted,
Mine eare hath tempted iudgement to deſire.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: Then Warwicke, thus:
Our Siſter ſhall be Edwards.
And now forthwith ſhall Articles be drawne,
Touching the Ioynture that your King muſt make,
Which with her Dowrie ſhall be counter-poys’d:
Draw neere, Queene Margaret, and be a witneſſe,
That Bona ſhall be Wife to the Engliſh King.

speech.speaker: Pr.Edw.
speech.line: To Edward, but not to the Engliſh King.

speech.speaker: Marg.
speech.line: Deceitfull Warwicke, it was thy deuice,
By this alliance to make void my ſuit:
Before thy comming, Lewis was Henries friend.

speech.speaker: Lewis.
speech.line: And ſtill is friend to him, and Margaret.
But if your Title to the Crowne be weake,
As may appeare by Edwards good ſucceſſe:
Then ’tis but reaſon, that I be releas’d
From giuing ayde, which late I promiſed.
Yet ſhall you haue all kindneſſe at my hand,
That your Eſtate requires, and mine can yeeld.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Henry now liues in Scotland, at his eaſe;
Where hauing nothing, nothing can he loſe.
And as for you your ſelfe (our quondam Queene)
You haue a Father able to maintaine you,
And better ’twere, you troubled him, then France.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Peace impudent, and ſhameleſſe Warwicke,
Proud ſetter vp, and puller downe of Kings,
I will not hence, till with my Talke and Teares
(Both full of Truth) I make King Lewis behold
Thy ſlye conueyance, and thy Lords falſe loue,
For both of you are Birds of ſelfe-ſame Feather.

speech.speaker: Lewes.
speech.line: Warwicke, this is ſome poſte to vs, or thee.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: My Lord Ambaſſador,
Theſe Letters are for you.
Sent from your Brother Marqueſſe Montague.
Theſe from our King, vnto your Maieſty.
And Madam, theſe for you:
From whom, I know not.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I like it well, that our faire Queene and Miſtris
Smiles at her newes, while Warwicke frownes at his.

speech.speaker: Prince Ed.
speech.line: Nay marke how Lewis ſtampes as he were
netled. I hope, all’s for the beſt.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Warwicke, what are thy Newes?
And yours, faire Queene.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Mine ſuch, as ﬁll my heart with vnhop’d ioyes.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Mine full of ſorrow, and hearts diſcontent.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: What? has your King married the Lady Grey?
And now to ſooth your Forgery, and his,
Sends me a Paper to perſwade me Patience?
Is this th’Alliance that he ſeekes with France?
Dare he preſume to ſcorne vs in this manner?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: I told your Maieſty as much before:
This proueth Edwards Loue, and Warwickes honeſty.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: King Lewis, I heere proteſt in ſight of heauen,
And by the hope I haue of heauenly bliſſe,
That I am cleere from this miſdeed of Edwards;
No more my King, for he diſhonors me,
But moſt himſelfe, if he could ſee his ſhame.
Did I forget, that by the Houſe of Yorke
My Father came vntimely to his death?
Did I let paſſe th’abuſe done to my Neece?
Did I impale him with the Regall Crowne?
Did I put Henry from his Natiue Right?
And am I guerdon’d at the laſt, with Shame?
Shame on himſelfe, for my Deſert is Honor.
And to repaire my Honor loſt for him,
I heere renounce him, and returne to Henry.
My Noble Queene, let former grudges paſſe,
And henceforth, I am thy true Seruitour:
I will reuenge his wrong to Lady Bona,
And replant Henry in his former ſtate.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Warwicke,
Theſe words haue turn’d my Hate, to Loue,
And I forgiue, and quite forget old faults,
And ioy that thou becom’ſt King Henries Friend.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: So much his Friend, I, his vnfained Friend,
That if King Lewis vouchſafe to furniſh vs
With ſome few Bands of choſen Soldiours,
Ile vndertake to Land them on our Coaſt,
And force the Tyrant from his ſeat by Warre.
’Tis not his new-made Bride ſhall ſuccour him.
And as for Clarence, as my Letters tell me,
Hee’s very likely now to fall from him,
For matching more for wanton Luſt, then Honor,
Or then for ſtrength and ſafety of our Country.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Deere Brother, how ſhall Bona be reueng’d,
But by thy helpe to this diſtreſſed Queene?

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Renowned Prince, how ſhall Poore Henry liue,
Vnleſſe thou reſcue him from foule diſpaire?

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: My quarrel, and this Engliſh Queens, are one.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: And mine faire Lady Bona, ioynes with yours.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: And mine, with hers, and thine, and Margarets.
Therefore, at laſt, I ﬁrmely am reſolu’d
You ſhall haue ayde.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Let me giue humble thankes for all, at once.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Then Englands Meſſenger, returne in Poſte,
And tell falſe Edward, thy ſuppoſed King,
That Lewis of France, is ſending ouer Maskers
To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.
Thou ſeeſt what’s paſt, go feare thy King withall.

speech.speaker: Bona.
speech.line: Tell him, in hope hee’l proue a widower ſhortly,
I weare the Willow Garland for his ſake.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Tell him, my mourning weeds are layde aſide,
And I am ready to put Armor on.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore Ile vn-Crowne him, er’t be long.
There’s thy reward, be gone.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: But Warwicke,
Thou and Oxford, with ﬁue thouſand men
Shall croſſe the Seas, and bid falſe Edward battaile:
And as occaſion ſerues, this Noble Queen
And Prince, ſhall follow with a freſh Supply.
Yet ere thou go, but anſwer me one doubt:
What Pledge haue we of thy ﬁrme Loyalty?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: This ſhall aſſure my conſtant Loyalty,
That if our Queene, and this young Prince agree,
Ile ioyne mine eldeſt daughter, and my Ioy,
To him forthwith, in holy Wedlocke bands.

speech.speaker: Mar.
speech.line: Yes, I agree, and thanke you for your Motion.
Sonne Edward, ſhe is Faire and Vertuous,
Therefore delay not, giue thy hand to Warwicke,
And with thy hand, thy faith irreuocable,
That onely Warwickes daughter ſhall be thine.

speech.speaker: Prin.Ed.
speech.line: Yes, I accept her, for ſhe well deſerues it,
And heere to pledge my Vow, I giue my hand.

scene.stagedir: He giues his hand to Warw.

speech.speaker: Lew.
speech.line: Why ſtay we now? Theſe ſoldiers ſhalbe leuied,
And thou Lord Bourbon, our High Admirall
Shall waﬅ them ouer with our Royall Fleete.
I long till Edward fall by Warres miſchance,
For mocking Marriage with a Dame of France.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I came from Edward as Ambaſſador,
But I returne his ſworne and mortall Fœ:
Matter of Marriage was the charge he gaue me,
But dreadfull Warre ſhall anſwer his demand.
Had he none elſe to make a ſtale but me?
Then none but I, ſhall turne his Ieſt to Sorrow.
I was the Cheefe that rais’d him to the Crowne,
And Ile be Cheefe to bring him downe againe:
Not that I pitty Henries miſery,
But ſeeke Reuenge on Edwards mockery.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, Clarence, Somerſet, and Mountague.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now tell me Brother Clarence, what thinke you
Of this new Marriage with the Lady Gray?
Hath not our Brother made a worthy choice?

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Alas, you know, tis farre from hence to France,
How could he ſtay till Warwicke made returne?

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: My Lords, forbeare this talke: heere comes the
King.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter King Edward, Lady Grey, Penbrooke, Stafford, Haſtings: foure ſtand on one ſide, and foure on the other.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And his well-choſen Bride.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: I minde to tell him plainly what I thinke.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Brother of Clarence,
How like you our Choyce,
That you ſtand penſiue, as halfe malecontent?

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: As well as Lewis of France,
Or the Earle of Warwicke,
Which are ſo weake of courage, and in iudgement,
That they’le take no offence at our abuſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Suppoſe they take offence without a cauſe:
They are but Lewis and Warwicke, I am Edward,
Your King and Warwickes, and muſt haue my will.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And ſhall haue your will, becauſe our King:
Yet haſtie Marriage ſeldome proueth well.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Yea, Brother Richard, are you offended too?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Not I: no:
God forbid, that I ſhould wiſh them ſeuer’d,
Whom God hath ioyn’d together:
I, and ’twere pittie, to ſunder them,
That yoake ſo well together.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Setting your ſkornes, and your miſlike aſide,
Tell me ſome reaſon, why the Lady Grey
Should not become my Wife, and Englands Queene?
And you too, Somerſet, and Mountague,
Speake freely what you thinke.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Then this is mine opinion:
That King Lewis becomes your Enemie,
For mocking him about the Marriage
Of the Lady Bona.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And Warwicke, doing what you gaue in charge,
Is now dis-honored by this new Marriage.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What, if both Lewis and Warwick be appeas’d,
By ſuch inuention as I can deuiſe?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Yet, to haue ioyn’d with France in ſuch alliance,
Would more haue ſtrength’ned this our Commonwealth
’Gainſt forraine ſtormes, then any home-bred Marriage.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Why, knowes not Mountague, that of it ſelfe,
England is ſafe, if true within it ſelfe?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: But the ſafer, when ’tis back’d with France.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: ’Tis better vſing France, then truſting France:
Let vs be back’d with God, and with the Seas,
Which he hath giu’n for fence impregnable,
And with their helpes, onely defend our ſelues:
In them, and in our ſelues, our ſafetie lyes.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: For this one ſpeech, Lord Haſtings well deſerues
To haue the Heire of the Lord Hungerford.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I, what of that? it was my will, and graunt,
And for this once, my Will ſhall ſtand for Law.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And yet me thinks, your Grace hath not done well,
To giue the Heire and Daughter of Lord Scales
Vnto the Brother of your louing Bride;
Shee better would haue ﬁtted me, or Clarence:
But in your Bride you burie Brotherhood.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Or elſe you would not haue beſtow’d the Heire
Of the Lord Bonuill on your new Wiues Sonne,
And leaue your Brothers to gœ ſpeede elſewhere.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Alas, poore Clarence: is it for a Wife
That thou art malecontent? I will prouide thee.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: In chuſing for your ſelfe,
You ſhew’d your iudgement:
Which being ſhallow, you ſhall giue me leaue
To play the Broker in mine owne behalfe;
And to that end, I ſhortly minde to leaue you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Leaue me, or tarry, Edward will be King,
And not be ty’d vnto his Brothers will.

speech.speaker: Lady Grey.
speech.line: My Lords, before it pleas’d his Maieſtie
To rayſe my State to Title of a Queene,
Dœ me but right, and you muſt all confeſſe,
That I was not ignoble of Deſcent,
And meaner then my ſelfe haue had like fortune.
But as this Title honors me and mine,
So your diſlikes, to whom I would be pleaſing,
Doth cloud my ioyes with danger, and with ſorrow.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Loue, forbeare to fawne vpon their frownes:
What danger, or what ſorrow can befall thee,
So long as Edward is thy conſtant friend,
And their true Soueraigne, whom they muſt obey?
Nay, whom they ſhall obey, and loue thee too,
Vnleſſe they ſeeke for hatred at my hands:
Which if they dœ, yet will I keepe thee ſafe,
And they ſhall feele the vengeance of my wrath.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I heare, yet ſay not much, but thinke the more.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now Meſſenger, what Letters, or what Newes
from France?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: My Soueraigne Liege, no Letters, & few words,
But ſuch, as I (without your ſpeciall pardon)
Dare not relate.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Gœ too, wee pardon thee:
Therefore, in briefe, tell me their words,
As neere as thou canſt gueſſe them.
What anſwer makes King Lewis vnto our Letters?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: At my depart, theſe were his very words:
Gœ tell falſe Edward, the ſuppoſed King,
That Lewis of France is ſending ouer Maskers,
To reuell it with him, and his new Bride.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Is Lewis ſo braue? belike he thinkes me Henry.
But what ſaid Lady Bona to my Marriage?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Theſe were her words, vtt’red with mild diſdaine:
Tell him, in hope hee’le proue a Widower ſhortly,
Ile weare the Willow Garland for his ſake.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: I blame not her; ſhe could ſay little leſſe:
She had the wrong. But what ſaid Henries Queene?
For I haue heard, that ſhe was there in place.

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: Tell him (quoth ſhe)
My mourning Weedes are done,
And I am readie to put Armour on.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Belike ſhe minds to play the Amazon.
But what ſaid Warwicke to theſe iniuries?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: He, more incens’d againſt your Maieſtie,
Then all the reſt, diſcharg’d me with theſe words:
Tell him from me, that he hath done me wrong,
And therefore Ile vncrowne him, er’t be long.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Ha? durſt the Traytor breath out ſo prowd words?
Well, I will arme me, being thus fore-warn’d:
They ſhall haue Warres, and pay for their preſumption.
But ſay, is Warwicke friends with Margaret?

speech.speaker: Poſt.
speech.line: I, gracious Soueraigne,
They are ſo link’d in friendſhip,
That yong Prince Edward marryes Warwicks Daughter.

speech.speaker: Clarence.
speech.line: Belike, the elder;
Clarence will haue the younger.
Now Brother King farewell, and ſit you faſt,
For I will hence to Warwickes other Daughter,
That though I want a Kingdome, yet in Marriage
I may not proue inferior to your ſelfe.
You that loue me, and Warwicke, follow me.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Not I:
My thoughts ayme at a further matter:
I ſtay not for the loue of Edward, but the Crowne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Clarence and Somerſet both gone to Warwicke?
Yet am I arm’d againſt the worſt can happen:
And haſte is needfull in this deſp’rate caſe.
Pembrooke and Stafford, you in our behalfe
Gœ leuie men, and make prepare for Warre;
They are alreadie, or quickly will be landed:
My ſelfe in perſon will ſtraight follow you.
But ere I gœ, Haſtings and Mountague
Reſolue my doubt: you twaine, of all the reſt,
Are neere to Warwicke, by bloud, and by allyance:
Tell me, if you loue Warwicke more then me;
If it be ſo, then both depart to him:
I rather wiſh you fœs, then hollow friends.
But if you minde to hold your true obedience,
Giue me aſſurance with ſome friendly Vow,
That I may neuer haue you in ſuſpe.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: So God helpe Mountague, as hee proues
true.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: And Hastings, as hee fauours Edwards cauſe.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now, Brother Richard, will you ſtand by vs?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, in deſpight of all that ſhall withſtand you.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Why ſo: then am I ſure of Viorie.
Now therefore let vs hence, and loſe no howre,
Till wee meet Warwicke, with his forreine powre.

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke and Oxford in England, with French Souldiors.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Truſt me, my Lord, all hitherto gœs well,
The common people by numbers ſwarme to vs.
But ſee where Somerſet and Clarence comes:
Speake ſuddenly, my Lords, are wee all friends?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Feare not that, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Then gentle Clarence, welcome vnto Warwicke,
And welcome Somerſet: I hold it cowardize,
To reſt miſtruſtfull, where a Noble Heart
Hath pawn’d an open Hand, in ſigne of Loue;
Elſe might I thinke, that Clarence, Edwards Brother,
Were but a fained friend to our proceedings:
But welcome ſweet Clarence, my Daughter ſhall be thine.
And now, what reſts? but in Nights Couerture,
Thy Brother being careleſſely encamp’d,
His Souldiors lurking in the Towne about,
And but attended by a ſimple Guard,
Wee may ſurprize and take him at our pleaſure,
Our Scouts haue found the aduenture very eaſie:
That as Vlyſſes, and ſtout Diomede,
With ſleight and manhood ſtole to Rheſus Tents,
And brought from thence the Thracian fatall Steeds;
So wee, well couer’d with the Nights black Mantle,
At vnawares may beat downe Edwards Guard,
And ſeize himſelfe: I ſay not, ſlaughter him,
For I intend but onely to ſurprize him.
You that will follow me to this attempt,
Applaud the Name of Henry, with your Leader.
Why then, let’s on our way in ſilent ſort,
For Warwicke and his friends, God and Saint George.

scene.stagedir: Enter three Watchmen to guard the Kings Tent.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Come on my Maſters, each man take his ſtand,
The King by this, is ſet him downe to ſleepe.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: What, will he not to Bed?

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Why, no: for he hath made a ſolemne Vow,
Neuer to lye and take his naturall Reſt,
Till Warwicke, or himſelfe, be quite ſuppreſt.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: To morrow then belike ſhall be the day,
If Warwicke be ſo neere as men report.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: But ſay, I pray, what Noble man is that,
That with the King here reſteth in his Tent?

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: ’Tis the Lord Haſtings, the Kings chiefeſt
friend.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: O, is it ſo? but why commands the King,
That his chiefe followers lodge in Townes about him,
While he himſelfe keepes in the cold ﬁeld?

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: ’Tis the more honour, becauſe more dange —
rous.

speech.speaker: 3.Watch.
speech.line: I, but giue me worſhip, and quietneſſe,
I like it better then a dangerous honor.
If Warwicke knew in what eſtate he ſtands,
’Tis to be doubted if he would waken him.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Vnleſſe our Halberds did ſhut vp his paſ —
ſage.

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: I: wherefore elſe guard we his Royall Tent,
But to defend his Perſon from Night-fœs?

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke, Clarence, Oxford, Somerſet, and French Souldiors, ſilent all.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: This is his Tent, and ſee where ſtand his Guard:
Courage my Maſters: Honor now, or neuer:
But follow me, and Edward ſhall be ours.

speech.speaker: 1.Watch.
speech.line: Who gœs there?

speech.speaker: 2.Watch.
speech.line: Stay, or thou dyeſt.

scene.stagedir: Warwicke and the reſt cry all, Warwicke, Warwicke, and ſet vpon the Guard, who ﬂye, crying, Arme, Arme, Warwicke and the reſt following them.
The Drumme playing, and Trumpet ſounding. Enter Warwicke, Somerſet, and the reſt, bringing the King out in his Gowne, ſitting in a Chaire: Richard and Haſtings ﬂyes ouer the Stage.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: What are they that ﬂye there?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Richard and Haſtings: let them gœ, heere is
the Duke.

speech.speaker: K.Edw.
speech.line: The Duke?
Why Warwicke, when wee parted,
Thou call’dſt me King.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: I, but the caſe is alter’d.
When you diſgrac’d me in my Embaſſade,
Then I degraded you from being King,
And come now to create you Duke of Yorke.
Alas, how ſhould you gouerne any Kingdome,
That know not how to vſe Embaſſadors,
Nor how to be contented with one Wife,
Nor how to vſe your Brothers Brotherly,
Nor how to ſtudie for the Peoples Welfare,
Nor how to ſhrowd your ſelfe from Enemies?

speech.speaker: K.Edw.
speech.line: Yea, Brother of Clarence,
Art thou here too?
Nay then I ſee, that Edward needs muſt downe.
Yet Warwicke, in deſpight of all miſchance,
Of thee thy ſelfe, and all thy Complices,
Edward will alwayes beare himſelfe as King:
Though Fortunes mallice ouerthrow my State,
My minde exceedes the compaſſe of her Wheele.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Then for his minde, be Edward Englands King,
But Henry now ſhall weare the Engliſh Crowne,
And be true King indeede: thou but the ſhadow.
My Lord of Somerſet, at my requeſt,
See that forthwith Duke Edward be conuey’d
Vnto my Brother Arch-Biſhop of Yorke:
When I haue fought with Pembrooke, and his fellowes,
Ile follow you, and tell what anſwer
Lewis and the Lady Bona ſend to him.
Now for a-while farewell good Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: What Fates impoſe, that men muſt needs abide;
It boots not to reſiſt both winde and tide.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: What now remaines my Lords for vs to do,
But march to London with our Soldiers?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I, that’s the ﬁrſt thing that we haue to do,
To free King Henry from impriſonment,
And ſee him ſeated in the Regall Throne.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Madam, what makes you in this ſodain change?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: Why Brother Riuers, are you yet to learne
What late misfortune is befalne King Edward?

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: What loſſe of ſome pitcht battell
Againſt Warwicke?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: No, but the loſſe of his owne Royall perſon.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Then is my Soueraigne ſlaine?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: I almoſt ſlaine, for he is taken priſoner,
Either betrayd by falſhood of his Guard,
Or by his Fœ ſurpriz’d at vnawares:
And as I further haue to vnderſtand,
Is new committed to the Biſhop of Yorke,
Fell Warwickes Brother, and by that our Fœ.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: Theſe Newes I muſt confeſſe are full of greefe,
Yet gracious Madam, beare it as you may,
Warwicke may looſe, that now hath wonne the day.

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: Till then, faire hope muſt hinder liues decay:
And I the rather waine me from diſpaire
For loue of Edwards Off-ſpring in my wombe:
This is it that makes me bridle paſſion,
And beare with Mildneſſe my miſfortunes croſſe:
I, I, for this I draw in many a teare,
And ſtop the riſing of blood-ſucking ſighes,
Leaſt with my ſighes or teares, I blaſt or drowne
King Edwards Fruite, true heyre to th’ Engliſh Crowne.

speech.speaker: Riu.
speech.line: But Madam,
Where is Warwicke then become?

speech.speaker: Gray.
speech.line: I am inform’d that he comes towards London,
To ſet the Crowne once more on Henries head,
Gueſſe thou the reſt, King Edwards Friends muſt downe.
But to preuent the Tyrants violence,
(For truſt not him that hath once broken Faith)
Ile hence forthwith vnto the Sanuary,
To ſaue (at leaſt) the heire of Edwards right:
There ſhall I reſt ſecure from force and fraud:
Come therefore let vs ﬂye, while we may ﬂye,
If Warwicke take vs, we are ſure to dye.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard, Lord Haſtings, and Sir William Stanley.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Now my Lord Haſtings, and Sir William Stanley
Leaue off to wonder why I drew you hither,
Into this cheefeſt Thicket of the Parke.
Thus ſtand the caſe: you know our King, my Brother,
Is priſoner to the Biſhop here, at whoſe hands
He hath good vſage, and great liberty,
And oﬅen but attended with weake guard,
Come hunting this way to diſport himſelfe.
I haue aduertis’d him by ſecret meanes,
That if about this houre he make this way,
Vnder the colour of his vſuall game,
He ſhall heere ﬁnde his Friends with Horſe and Men,
To ſet him free from his Captiuitie.

scene.stagedir: Enter King Edward, and a Huntſman with him.

speech.speaker: Huntſman.
speech.line: This way my Lord,
For this way lies the Game.

speech.speaker: King Edw.
speech.line: Nay this way man,
See where the Huntſmen ſtand.
Now Brother of Gloſter, Lord Haſtings, and the reſt,
Stand you thus cloſe to ſteale the Biſhops Deere?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother, the time and caſe, requireth haſt,
Your horſe ſtands ready at the Parke-corner.

speech.speaker: King Ed.
speech.line: But whether ſhall we then?

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: To Lyn my Lord,
And ſhipt from thence to Flanders.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Wel gueſt beleeue me, for that was my meaning

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Stanley, I will requite thy forwardneſſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But wherefore ſtay we? ’tis no time to talke.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Huntſman, what ſay’ſt thou?
Wilt thou go along?

speech.speaker: Huntſ.
speech.line: Better do ſo, then tarry and be hang’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come then away, lets ha no more adoo.

speech.speaker: K.Ed.
speech.line: Biſhop farwell,
Sheeld thee from Warwickes frowne,
And pray that I may re-poſſeſſe the Crowne.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter King Henry the ſixt, Clarence, Warwicke, Somerſet, young Henry, Oxford, Mountague, and Lieutenant.

speech.speaker: K.Hen.
speech.line: M. Lieutenant, now that God and Friends
Haue ſhaken Edward from the Regall ſeate,
And turn’d my captiue ſtate to libertie,
My feare to hope, my ſorrowes vnto ioyes,
At our enlargement what are thy due Fees?

speech.speaker: Lieu.
speech.line: Subies may challenge nothing of their Sou’rains
But, if an humble prayer may preuaile,
I then craue pardon of your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: K.Hen.
speech.line: For what, Lieutenant? For well vſing me?
Nay, be thou ſure, Ile well requite thy kindneſſe.
For that it made my impriſonment, a pleaſure:
I, ſuch a pleaſure, as incaged Birds
Conceiue; when aﬅer many moody Thoughts,
At laſt, by Notes of Houſhold harmonie,
They quite forget their loſſe of Libertie.
But Warwicke, aﬅer God, thou ſet’ſt me free,
And chiefely therefore, I thanke God, and thee,
He was the Author, thou the Inſtrument.
Therefore that I may conquer Fortunes ſpight,
By liuing low, where Fortune cannot hurt me,
And that the people of this bleſſed Land
May not be puniſht with my thwarting ſtarres,
Warwicke, although my Head ſtill weare the Crowne,
I here reſigne my Gouernment to thee,
For thou art fortunate in all thy deeds.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Your Grace hath ſtill beene fam’d for vertuous,
And now may ſeeme as wiſe as vertuous,
By ſpying and auoiding Fortunes malice,
For few men rightly temper with the Starres:
Yet in this one thing let me blame your Grace,
For chuſing me, when Clarence is in place.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: No Warwicke, thou art worthy of the ſway,
To whom the Heau’ns in thy Natiuitie,
Adiudg’d an Oliue Branch, and Lawrell Crowne,
As likely to be bleſt in Peace and Warre:
And therefore I yeeld thee my free conſent.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: And I chuſe Clarence onely for Proteor.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Warwick and Clarence, giue me both your Hands:
Now ioyne your Hands, & with your Hands your Hearts,
That no diſſention hinder Gouernment:
I make you both Proteors of this Land,
While I my ſelfe will lead a priuate Life,
And in deuotion ſpend my latter dayes,
To ſinnes rebuke, and my Creators prayſe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What anſweres Clarence to his Soueraignes
will?

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: That he conſents, if Warwicke yeeld conſent,
For on thy fortune I repoſe my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why then, though loth, yet muſt I be content:
Wee’le yoake together, like a double ſhadow
To Henries Body, and ſupply his place;
I meane, in bearing weight of Gouernment,
While he enioyes the Honor, and his eaſe.
And Clarence, now then it is more then needfull,
Forthwith that Edward be pronounc’d a Traytor,
And all his Lands and Goods conﬁſcate.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: What elſe? and that Succeſſion be determined.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: I, therein Clarence ſhall not want his part.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: But with the ﬁrſt, of all your chiefe affaires,
Let me entreat (for I command no more)
That Margaret your Queene, and my Sonne Edward,
Be ſent for, to returne from France with ſpeed:
For till I ſee them here, by doubtfull feare,
My ioy of libertie is halfe eclips’d.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: It ſhall bee done, my Soueraigne, with all
ſpeede.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: My Lord of Somerſet, what Youth is that,
Of whom you ſeeme to haue ſo tender care?

speech.speaker: Somerſ.
speech.line: My Liege, it is young Henry, Earle of Rich —
mond.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Come hither, Englands Hope:
speech.stagedir: Layes his Hand on his Head.
speech.line: If ſecret Powers ſuggeſt but truth
To my diuining thoughts,
This prettie Lad will proue our Countries bliſſe.
His Lookes are full of peacefull Maieſtie,
His Head by nature fram’d to weare a Crowne,
His Hand to wield a Scepter, and himſelfe
Likely in time to bleſſe a Regall Throne:
Make much of him, my Lords; for this is hee
Muſt helpe you more, then you are hurt by mee.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: What newes, my friend?

speech.speaker: Poſte.
speech.line: That Edward is eſcaped from your Brother,
And ﬂed (as hee heares ſince) to Burgundie.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Vnſauorie newes: but how made he eſcape?

speech.speaker: Poſte.
speech.line: He was conuey’d by Richard, Duke of Gloſter,
And the Lord Haſtings, who attended him
In ſecret ambuſh, on the Forreſt ſide,
And from the Biſhops Huntſmen reſcu’d him:
For Hunting was his dayly Exerciſe.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: My Brother was too careleſſe of his charge.
But let vs hence, my Soueraigne, to prouide
A ſalue for any ſore, that may betide.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: My Lord, I like not of this ﬂight of Edwards:
For doubtleſſe, Burgundie will yeeld him helpe,
And we ſhall haue more Warres befor’t be long.
As Henries late preſaging Prophecie
Did glad my heart, with hope of this young Richmond:
So doth my heart miſ-giue me, in theſe Conﬂis,
What may befall him, to his harme and ours.
Therefore, Lord Oxford, to preuent the worſt,
Forthwith wee’le ſend him hence to Brittanie,
Till ſtormes be paſt of Ciuill Enmitie.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I: for if Edward re-poſſeſſe the Crowne,
’Tis like that Richmond, with the reſt, ſhall downe.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: It ſhall be ſo: he ſhall to Brittanie.
Come therefore, let’s about it ſpeedily.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Edward, Richard, Haſtings, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now Brother Richard, Lord Haſtings, and the reſt,
Yet thus farre Fortune maketh vs amends,
And ſayes, that once more I ſhall enterchange
My wained ſtate, for Henries Regall Crowne.
Well haue we paſs’d, and now re-paſs’d the Seas,
And brought deſired helpe from Burgundie.
What then remaines, we being thus arriu’d
From Rauenſpurre Hauen, before the Gates of Yorke,
But that we enter, as into our Dukedome?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Gates made faſt?
Brother, I like not this.
For many men that ſtumble at the Threſhold,
Are well fore-told, that danger lurkes within.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Tuſh man, aboadments muſt not now affright vs:
By faire or foule meanes we muſt enter in,
For hither will our friends repaire to vs.

speech.speaker: Hast.
speech.line: My Liege, Ile knocke once more, to ſummon
them.

scene.stagedir: Enter on the Walls, the Maior of Yorke, and his Brethren.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: My Lords,
We were fore-warned of your comming,
And ſhut the Gates, for ſafetie of our ſelues;
For now we owe allegeance vnto Henry.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: But, Maſter Maior, if Henry be your King,
Yet Edward, at the leaſt, is Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: True, my good Lord, I know you for no
leſſe.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Why, and I challenge nothing but my Dukedome,
As being well content with that alone.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: But when the Fox hath once got in his Noſe,
Hee’le ſoone ﬁnde meanes to make the Body follow.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Why, Maſter Maior, why ſtand you in a doubt?
Open the Gates, we are King Henries friends.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: I, ſay you ſo? the Gates ſhall then be opened.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: A wiſe ſtout Captaine, and ſoone perſwaded.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: The good old man would faine that all were wel,
So ’twere not long of him: but being entred,
I doubt not I, but we ſhall ſoone perſwade
Both him, and all his Brothers, vnto reaſon.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Maior, and two Aldermen.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So, Maſter Maior: theſe Gates muſt not be ſhut,
But in the Night, or in the time of Warre.
What, feare not man, but yeeld me vp the Keyes,
For Edward will defend the Towne, and thee,
And all thoſe friends, that deine to follow mee.

scene.stagedir: March. Enter Mountgomerie, with Drumme and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Brother, this is Sir Iohn Mountgomerie,
Our truſtie friend, vnleſſe I be deceiu’d.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Welcome Sir Iohn: but why come you in
Armes?

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: To helpe King Edward in his time of ſtorme,
As euery loyall Subie ought to dœ.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thankes good Mountgomerie:
But we now forget our Title to the Crowne,
And onely clayme our Dukedome,
Till God pleaſe to ſend the reſt.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Then fare you well, for I will hence againe,
I came to ſerue a King, and not a Duke:
Drummer ſtrike vp, and let vs march away.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Nay ſtay, Sir Iohn, a while, and wee’le debate
By what ſafe meanes the Crowne may be recouer’d.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: What talke you of debating? in few words,
If you’le not here proclaime your ſelfe our King,
Ile leaue you to your fortune, and be gone,
To keepe them back, that come to ſuccour you.
Why ſhall we ﬁght, if you pretend no Title?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why Brother, wherefore ſtand you on nice
points?

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: When wee grow ſtronger,
Then wee’le make our Clayme:
Till then, ’tis wiſdome to conceale our meaning.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Away with ſcrupulous Wit, now Armes muſt
rule.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And feareleſſe minds clyme ſooneſt vnto Crowns.
Brother, we will proclaime you out of hand,
The bruit thereof will bring you many friends.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Then be it as you will: for ’tis my right,
And Henry but vſurpes the Diademe.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: I, now my Soueraigne ſpeaketh like himſelfe,
And now will I be Edwards Champion.

speech.speaker: Haſt.
speech.line: Sound Trumpet, Edward ſhal be here proclaim’d:
Come, fellow Souldior, make thou proclamation.

speech.speaker: Soul.
speech.line: Edward the Fourth, by the Grace of God, King of

line.emph: England and France, and Lord of Ireland, &c.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: And whoſœ’re gainſayes King Edwards right,
By this I challenge him to ſingle ﬁght.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Long liue Edward the Fourth.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Thankes braue Mountgomery,
And thankes vnto you all:
If fortune ſerue me, Ile requite this kindneſſe.
Now for this Night, let’s harbor here in Yorke:
And when the Morning Sunne ſhall rayſe his Carre
Aboue the Border of this Horizon,
Wee’le forward towards Warwicke, and his Mates;
For well I wot, that Henry is no Souldier.
Ah froward Clarence, how euill it beſeemes thee,
To ﬂatter Henry, and forſake thy Brother?
Yet as wee may, wee’le meet both thee and Warwicke.
Come on braue Souldiors: doubt not of the Day,
And that once gotten, doubt not of large Pay.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter the King, Warwicke, Mountague, Clarence, Oxford, and Somerſet.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: What counſaile, Lords? Edward from Belgia,
With haſtie Germanes, and blunt Hollanders,
Hath paſs’d in ſafetie through the Narrow Seas,
And with his troupes doth march amaine to London,
And many giddie people ﬂock to him.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Let’s leuie men, and beat him backe againe.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: A little ﬁre is quickly trodden out,
Which being ſuffer’d, Riuers cannot quench.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: In Warwickſhire I haue true-hearted friends,
Not mutinous in peace, yet bold in Warre,
Thoſe will I muſter vp: and thou Sonne Clarence
Shalt ſtirre vp in Suffolke, Norfolke, and in Kent,
The Knights and Gentlemen, to come with thee.
Thou Brother Mountague, in Buckingham,
Northampton, and in Leiceſterſhire, ſhalt ﬁnd
Men well enclin’d to heare what thou command’ſt.
And thou, braue Oxford, wondrous well belou’d,
In Oxfordſhire ſhalt muſter vp thy friends.
My Soueraigne, with the louing Citizens,
Like to his Iland, gyrt in with the Ocean,
Or modeſt Dyan, circled with her Nymphs,
Shall reſt in London, till we come to him:
Faire Lords take leaue, and ſtand not to reply.
Farewell my Soueraigne.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Farewell my Heor, and my Troyes true hope.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: In ſigne of truth, I kiſſe your Highneſſe Hand.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Well-minded Clarence, be thou fortunate.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Comfort, my Lord, and ſo I take my leaue.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: And thus I ſeale my truth, and bid adieu.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Sweet Oxford, and my louing Mountague,
And all at once, once more a happy farewell.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Farewell, ſweet Lords, let’s meet at Couentry.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Here at the Pallace will I reſt a while.
Couſin of Exeter, what thinkes your Lordſhip?
Me thinkes, the Power that Edward hath in ﬁeld,
Should not be able to encounter mine.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: The doubt is, that he will ſeduce the reſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: That’s not my feare, my meed hath got me fame:
I haue not ſtopt mine eares to their demands,
Nor poſted off their ſuites with ſlow delayes,
My pittie hath beene balme to heale their wounds,
My mildneſſe hath allay’d their ſwelling griefes,
My mercie dry’d their water-ﬂowing teares.
I haue not been deſirous of their wealth,
Nor much oppreſt them with great Subſidies,
Nor forward of reuenge, though they much err’d.
Then why ſhould they loue Edward more then me?
No Exeter, theſe Graces challenge Grace:
And when the Lyon fawnes vpon the Lambe,
The Lambe will neuer ceaſe to follow him.

scene.stagedir: Shout within, A Lancaſter, A Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: Hearke, hearke, my Lord, what Shouts are
theſe?

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Seize on the ſhamefac’d Henry, beare him hence,
And once againe proclaime vs King of England.
You are the Fount, that makes ſmall Brookes to ﬂow,
Now ſtops thy Spring, my Sea ſhall ſuck them dry,
And ſwell ſo much the higher, by their ebbe.
Hence with him to the Tower, let him not ſpeake.
And Lords, towards Couentry bend we our courſe,
Where peremptorie Warwicke now remaines:
The Sunne ſhines hot, and if we vſe delay,
Cold biting Winter marres our hop’d-for Hay.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Away betimes, before his forces ioyne,
And take the great-growne Traytor vnawares:
Braue Warriors, march amaine towards Couentry.

scene.stagedir: Enter Warwicke, the Maior of Couentry, two Meſſengers, and others vpon the Walls.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Where is the Poſt that came from valiant Oxford?
How farre hence is thy Lord, mine honeſt fellow?

speech.speaker: Meſſ. 1.
speech.line: By this at Dunſmore, marching hitherward.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: How farre off is our Brother Mountague?
Where is the Poſt that came from Mountague?

speech.speaker: Meſſ. 2.
speech.line: By this at Daintry, with a puiſſant troope.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Say Someruile, what ſayes my louing Sonne?
And by thy gueſſe, how nigh is Clarence now?

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: At Southam I did leaue him with his forces,
And dœ expe him here ſome two howres hence.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Then Clarence is at hand, I heare his Drumme.

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: It is not his, my Lord, here Southam lyes:
The Drum your Honor heares, marcheth from Warwicke.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Who ſhould that be? belike vnlook’d for friends.

speech.speaker: Someru.
speech.line: They are at hand, and you ſhall quickly know.

scene.stagedir: March. Flouriſh. Enter Edward, Richard, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Gœ, Trumpet, to the Walls, and ſound a Parle.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: See how the ſurly Warwicke mans the Wall.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh vnbid ſpight, is ſportfull Edward come?
Where ſlept our Scouts, or how are they ſeduc’d,
That we could heare no newes of his repayre.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now Warwicke, wilt thou ope the Citie Gates,
Speake gentle words, and humbly bend thy Knee,
Call Edward King, and at his hands begge Mercy,
And he ſhall pardon thee theſe Outrages?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Nay rather, wilt thou draw thy forces hence,
Confeſſe who ſet thee vp, and pluckt thee downe,
Call Warwicke Patron, and be penitent,
And thou ſhalt ſtill remaine the Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I thought at leaſt he would haue ſaid the King,
Or did he make the Ieaſt againſt his will?

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Is not a Dukedome, Sir, a goodly giﬅ?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, by my faith, for a poore Earle to giue,
Ile dœ thee ſeruice for ſo good a giﬅ.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: ’Twas I that gaue the Kingdome to thy Bro —
ther.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Why then ’tis mine, if but by Warwickes giﬅ.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Thou art no Atlas for ſo great a weight:
And Weakeling, Warwicke takes his giﬅ againe,
And Henry is my King, Warwicke his Subie.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: But Warwickes King is Edwards Priſoner:
And gallant Warwicke, dœ but anſwer this,
What is the Body, when the Head is off?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Alas, that Warwicke had no more fore-caſt,
But whiles he thought to ſteale the ſingle Ten,
The King was ſlyly ﬁnger’d from the Deck:
You leﬅ poore Henry at the Biſhops Pallace,
And tenne to one you’le meet him in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: ’Tis euen ſo, yet you are Warwicke ſtill.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Come Warwicke,
Take the time, kneele downe, kneele downe:
Nay when? ſtrike now, or elſe the Iron cooles.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I had rather chop this Hand off at a blow,
And with the other, ﬂing it at thy face,
Then beare ſo low a ſayle, to ſtrike to thee.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Sayle how thou canſt,
Haue Winde and Tyde thy friend,
This Hand, faſt wound about thy coale-black hayre,
Shall, whiles thy Head is warme, and new cut off,
Write in the duſt this Sentence with thy blood,
Wind-changing Warwicke now can change no more.

scene.stagedir: Enter Oxford, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh chearefull Colours, ſee where Oxford comes.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Oxford, Oxford, for Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Gates are open, let vs enter too.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So other fœs may ſet vpon our backs.
Stand we in good array: for they no doubt
Will iſſue out againe, and bid vs battaile;
If not, the Citie being but of ſmall defence,
Wee’le quickly rowze the Traitors in the ſame.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Oh welcome Oxford, for we want thy helpe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Mountague, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: Mount.
speech.line: Mountague, Mountague, for Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thou and thy Brother both ſhall buy this Treaſon
Euen with the deareſt blood your bodies beare.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: The harder matcht, the greater Viorie,
My minde preſageth happy gaine, and Conqueſt.

scene.stagedir: Enter Somerſet, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Somerſet, Somerſet, for Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Two of thy Name, both Dukes of Somerſet,
Haue ſold their Liues vnto the Houſe of Yorke,
And thou ſhalt be the third, if this Sword hold.

scene.stagedir: Enter Clarence, with Drumme and Colours.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: And lœ, where George of Clarence ſweepes along,
Of force enough to bid his Brother Battaile:
With whom, in vpright zeale to right, preuailes
More then the nature of a Brothers Loue.
Come Clarence, come: thou wilt, if Warwicke call.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Father of Warwicke, know you what this meanes?
Looke here, I throw my infamie at thee:
I will not ruinate my Fathers Houſe,
Who gaue his blood to lyme the ſtones together,
And ſet vp Lancaſter. Why, troweſt thou, Warwicke,
That Clarence is ſo harſh, ſo blunt vnnaturall,
To bend the fatall Inſtruments of Warre
Againſt his Brother, and his lawfull King.
Perhaps thou wilt obie my holy Oath:
To keepe that Oath, were more impietie,
Then Iephah, when he ſacriﬁc’d his Daughter.
I am ſo ſorry for my Treſpas made,
That to deſerue well at my Brothers hands,
I here proclayme my ſelfe thy mortall fœ:
With reſolution, whereſœ’re I meet thee,
(As I will meet thee, if thou ſtirre abroad)
To plague thee, for thy foule mis-leading me.
And ſo, prowd-hearted Warwicke, I deﬁe thee,
And to my Brother turne my bluſhing Cheekes.
Pardon me Edward, I will make amends:
And Richard, dœ not frowne vpon my faults,
For I will henceforth be no more vnconſtant.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now welcome more, and ten times more belou’d,
Then if thou neuer hadſt deſeru’d our hate.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Welcome good Clarence, this is Brother-like.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Oh paſſing Traytor, periur’d and vniuſt.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: What Warwicke,
Wilt thou leaue the Towne, and ﬁght?
Or ſhall we beat the Stones about thine Eares?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Alas, I am not coop’d here for defence:
I will away towards Barnet preſently,
And bid thee Battaile, Edward, if thou dar’ſt.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Yes Warwicke, Edward dares, and leads the way:
Lords to the ﬁeld: Saint George, and Viorie.

scene.stagedir: March. Warwicke and his companie followes.
Alarum, and Excurſions. Enter Edward bringing forth Warwicke wounded.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: So, lye thou there: dye thou, and dye our feare,
For Warwicke was a Bugge that fear’d vs all.
Now Mountague ſit faſt, I ſeeke for thee,
That Warwickes Bones may keepe thine companie.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Ah, who is nigh? come to me, friend, or fœ,
And tell me who is Vior, Yorke, or Warwicke?
Why aske I that? my mangled body ſhewes,
My blood, my want of ſtrength, my ſicke heart ſhewes,
That I muſt yeeld my body to the Earth,
And by my fall, the conqueſt to my fœ.
Thus yeelds the Cedar to the Axes edge,
Whoſe Armes gaue ſhelter to the Princely Eagle,
Vnder whoſe ſhade the ramping Lyon ſlept,
Whoſe top-branch ouer-peer’d Ioues ſpreading Tree,
And kept low Shrubs from Winters pow’rfull Winde.
Theſe Eyes, that now are dim’d with Deaths black Veyle,
Haue beene as piercing as the Mid-day Sunne,
To ſearch the ſecret Treaſons of the World:
The Wrinckles in my Browes, now ﬁll’d with blood,
Were lik’ned oﬅ to Kingly Sepulchers:
For who liu’d King, but I could digge his Graue?
And who durſt ſmile, when Warwicke bent his Brow?
Lœ, now my Glory ſmear’d in duſt and blood.
My Parkes, my Walkes, my Mannors that I had,
Euen now forſake me; and of all my Lands,
Is nothing leﬅ me, but my bodies length.
Why, what is Pompe, Rule, Reigne, but Earth and Duſt?
And liue we how we can, yet dye we muſt.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, Warwicke, wert thou as we are,
We might recouer all our Loſſe againe:
The Queene from France hath brought a puiſſant power.
Euen now we heard the newes: ah, could’ſt thou ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Why then I would not ﬂye. Ah Mountague,
If thou be there, ſweet Brother, take my Hand,
And with thy Lippes keepe in my Soule a while.
Thou lou’ſt me not: for, Brother, if thou didſt,
Thy teares would waſh this cold congealed blood,
That glewes my Lippes, and will not let me ſpeake.
Come quickly Mountague, or I am dead.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Ah Warwicke, Mountague hath breath’d his laſt,
And to the lateſt gaſpe, cry’d out for Warwicke:
And ſaid, Commend me to my valiant Brother.
And more he would haue ſaid, and more he ſpoke,
Which ſounded like a Cannon in a Vault,
That mought not be diſtinguiſht: but at laſt,
I well might heare, deliuered with a groane,
Oh farewell Warwicke.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Sweet reſt his Soule:
Flye Lords, and ſaue your ſelues,
For Warwicke bids you all farewell, to meet in Heauen.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Away, away, to meet the Queenes great power.

scene.stagedir: Here they beare away his Body. Exeunt.
Flouriſh. Enter King Edward in triumph, with Richard, Clarence, and the reſt.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Thus farre our fortune keepes an vpward courſe,
And we are grac’d with wreaths of Viorie:
But in the midſt of this bright-ſhining Day,
I ſpy a black ſuſpicious threatning Cloud,
That will encounter with our glorious Sunne,
Ere he attaine his eaſefull Weſterne Bed:
I meane, my Lords, thoſe powers that the Queene
Hath rays’d in Gallia, haue arriued our Coaſt,
And, as we heare, march on to ﬁght with vs.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: A little gale will ſoone diſperſe that Cloud,
And blow it to the Source from whence it came,
Thy very Beames will dry thoſe Vapours vp,
For euery Cloud engenders not a Storme.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: The Queene is valued thirtie thouſand ſtrong,
And Somerſet, with Oxford, ﬂed to her:
If ſhe haue time to breathe, be well aſſur’d
Her faion will be full as ſtrong as ours.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We are aduertis’d by our louing friends,
That they dœ hold their courſe toward Tewksbury.
We hauing now the beſt at Barnet ﬁeld,
Will thither ſtraight, for willingneſſe rids way,
And as we march, our ſtrength will be augmented:
In euery Countie as we gœ along,
Strike vp the Drumme, cry courage, and away.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. March. Enter the Queene, young Edward, Somerſet, Oxford, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Great Lords, wiſe men ne’r ſit and waile their loſſe,
But chearely ſeeke how to redreſſe their harmes.
What though the Maſt be now blowne ouer-boord,
The Cable broke, the holding-Anchor loſt,
And halfe our Saylors ſwallow’d in the ﬂood?
Yet liues our Pilot ſtill. Is’t meet, that hee
Should leaue the Helme, and like a fearefull Lad,
With tearefull Eyes adde Water to the Sea,
And giue more ſtrength to that which hath too much,
Whiles in his moane, the Ship ſplits on the Rock,
Which Induſtrie and Courage might haue ſau’d?
Ah what a ſhame, ah what a fault were this.
Say Warwicke was our Anchor: what of that?
And Mountague our Top-Maſt: what of him?
Our ſlaught’red friends, the Tackles: what of theſe?
Why is not Oxford here, another Anchor?
And Somerſet, another goodly Maſt?
The friends of France our Shrowds and Tacklings?
And though vnskilfull, why not Ned and I,
For once allow’d the skilfull Pilots Charge?
We will not from the Helme, to ſit and weepe,
But keepe our Courſe (though the rough Winde ſay no)
From Shelues and Rocks, that threaten vs with Wrack.
As good to chide the Waues, as ſpeake them faire.
And what is Edward, but a ruthleſſe Sea?
What Clarence, but a Quick-ſand of Deceit?
And Richard, but a raged fatall Rocke?
All theſe, the Enemies to our poore Barke.
Say you can ſwim, alas ’tis but a while:
Tread on the Sand, why there you quickly ſinke,
Beſtride the Rock, the Tyde will waſh you off,
Or elſe you famiſh, that’s a three-fold Death.
This ſpeake I (Lords) to let you vnderſtand,
If caſe ſome one of you would ﬂye from vs,
That there’s no hop’d-for Mercy with the Brothers,
More then with ruthleſſe Waues, with Sands and Rocks.
Why courage then, what cannot be auoided,
’Twere childiſh weakeneſſe to lament, or feare.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Me thinkes a Woman of this valiant Spirit,
Should, if a Coward heard her ſpeake theſe words,
Infuſe his Breaſt with Magnanimitie,
And make him, naked, foyle a man at Armes.
I ſpeake not this, as doubting any here:
For did I but ſuſpe a fearefull man,
He ſhould haue leaue to gœ away betimes,
Leaſt in our need he might infe another,
And make him of like ſpirit to himſelfe.
If any ſuch be here, as God forbid,
Let him depart, before we neede his helpe.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Women and Children of ſo high a courage,
And Warriors faint, why ’twere perpetuall ſhame.
Oh braue young Prince: thy famous Grandfather
Doth liue againe in thee; long may’ſt thou liue,
To beare his Image, and renew his Glories.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: And he that will not ﬁght for ſuch a hope,
Gœ home to Bed, and like the Owle by day,
If he ariſe, be mock’d and wondred at.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Thankes gentle Somerſet, ſweet Oxford thankes.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: And take his thankes, that yet hath nothing
elſe.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Prepare you Lords, for Edward is at hand,
Readie to ﬁght: therefore be reſolute.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: I thought no leſſe: it is his Policie,
To haſte thus faſt, to ﬁnde vs vnprouided.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: But hee’s deceiu’d, we are in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: This cheares my heart, to ſee your forwardneſſe.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: Here pitch our Battaile, hence we will not budge.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh, and march. Enter Edward, Richard, Clarence, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Braue followers, yonder ſtands the thornie Wood,
Which by the Heauens aſſiſtance, and your ſtrength,
Muſt by the Roots be hew’ne vp yet ere Night.
I need not adde more fuell to your ﬁre,
For well I wot, ye blaze, to burne them out:
Giue ſignall to the ﬁght, and to it Lords.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Lords, Knights, and Gentlemen, what I ſhould ſay,
My teares gaine-ſay: for euery word I ſpeake,
Ye ſee I drinke the water of my eye.
Therefore no more but this: Henry your Soueraigne
Is Priſoner to the Fœ, his State vſurp’d,
His Realme a ſlaughter-houſe, his Subies ſlaine,
His Statutes cancell’d, and his Treaſure ſpent:
And yonder is the Wolfe, that makes this ſpoyle.
You ﬁght in Iuſtice: then in Gods Name, Lords,
Be valiant, and giue ſignall to the ﬁght.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter Edward, Richard, Queene, Clarence, Oxford, Somerſet.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Now here a period of tumultuous Broyles.
Away with Oxford to Hames Caſtle ſtraight:
For Somerſet, off with his guiltie Head.
Gœ beare them hence, I will not heare them ſpeake.

speech.speaker: Oxf.
speech.line: For my part, Ile not trouble thee with words.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Nor I, but ſtoupe with patience to my fortune.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: So part we ſadly in this troublous World,
To meet with Ioy in ſweet Ieruſalem.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Is Proclamation made, That who ﬁnds Edward,
Shall haue a high Reward, and he his Life?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: It is, and lœ where youthfull Edward comes.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Bring forth the Gallant, let vs heare him ſpeake.
What? can ſo young a Thorne begin to prick?
Edward, what ſatisfaion canſt thou make,
For bearing Armes, for ſtirring vp my Subies,
And all the trouble thou haſt turn’d me to?

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Speake like a Subie, prowd ambitious Yorke.
Suppoſe that I am now my Fathers Mouth,
Reſigne thy Chayre, and where I ſtand, kneele thou,
Whil’ſt I propoſe the ſelfe-ſame words to thee,
Which (Traytor) thou would’ſt haue me anſwer to.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Ah, that thy Father had beene ſo reſolu’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: That you might ſtill haue worne the Petticoat,
And ne’re haue ſtolne the Breech from Lancaſter.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Let Æſop fable in a Winters Night,
His Curriſh Riddles ſorts not with this place.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: By Heauen, Brat, Ile plague ye for that word.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I, thou waſt borne to be a plague to men.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: For Gods ſake, take away this Captiue Scold.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: Nay, take away this ſcolding Crooke-backe,
rather.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Peace wilfull Boy, or I will charme your tongue.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: Vntutor’d Lad, thou art too malapert.

speech.speaker: Prince.
speech.line: I know my dutie, you are all vndutifull:
Laſciuious Edward, and thou periur’d George,
And thou miſ-ſhapen Dicke, I tell ye all,
I am your better, Traytors as ye are,
And thou vſurp’ſt my Fathers right and mine.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Take that, the likeneſſe of this Rayler here.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Sprawl’ſt thou? take that, to end thy agonie.

speech.speaker: Clar.
speech.line: And ther’s for twitting me with periurie.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh, kill me too.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Marry, and ſhall.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: Hold, Richard, hold, for we haue done too much.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why ſhould ſhee liue, to ﬁll the World with
words.

speech.speaker: Edw.
speech.line: What? doth ſhee ſwowne? vſe meanes for her
recouerie.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Clarence excuſe me to the King my Brother:
Ile hence to London on a ſerious matter,
Ere ye come there, be ſure to heare ſome newes.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: What? what?

speech.speaker: Rich
speech.line: Tower, the Tower.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Oh Ned, ſweet Ned, ſpeake to thy Mother Boy.
Can’ſt thou not ſpeake? O Traitors, Murtherers!
They that ſtabb’d Cæſar, ſhed no blood at all:
Did not offend, nor were not worthy Blame,
If this foule deed were by, to equall it.
He was a Man; this (in reſpe) a Childe,
And Men, ne’re ſpend their fury on a Childe.
What’s worſe then Murtherer, that I may name it?
No, no, my heart will burſt, and if I ſpeake,
And I will ſpeake, that ſo my heart may burſt.
Butchers and Villaines, bloudy Caniballes,
How ſweet a Plant haue you vntimely cropt:
You haue no children (Butchers) if you had,
The thought of them would haue ſtirr’d vp remorſe,
But if you euer chance to haue a Childe,
Looke in his youth to haue him ſo cut off.
As deathſmen you haue rid this ſweet yong Prince.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Away with her, go beare her hence perforce.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Nay, neuer beare me hence, diſpatch me heere:
Here ſheath thy Sword, Ile pardon thee my death:
What? wilt thou not? Then Clarence do it thou.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: By heauen, I will not do thee ſo much eaſe.

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: Good Clarence do: ſweet Clarence do thou do it.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Did’ſt thou not heare me ſweare I would not do it?

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: I, but thou vſeſt to forſweare thy ſelfe.
’Twas Sin before, but now ’tis Charity
What wilt ӳ not? Where is that diuels butcher Richard?
Hard fauor’d Richard? Richard, where art thou?
Thou art not heere; Murther is thy Almeſ-deed:
Petitioners for Blood, thou ne’re put’ſt backe.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Away I ſay, I charge ye beare her hence,

speech.speaker: Qu.
speech.line: So come to you, and yours, as to this Prince.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: Where’s Richard gone.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: To London all in poſt, and as I gueſſe,
To make a bloody Supper in the Tower.

speech.speaker: Ed.
speech.line: He’s ſodaine if a thing comes in his head.
Now march we hence, diſcharge the common ſort
With Pay and Thankes, and let’s away to London,
And ſee our gentle Queene how well ſhe fares,
By this (I hope) ſhe hath a Sonne for me.

scene.stagedir: Enter Henry the ſixt, and Richard, with the Lieutenant on the Walles.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Good day, my Lord, what at your Booke ſo
hard?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I my good Lord: my Lord I ſhould ſay rather,
Tis ſinne to ﬂatter, Good was little better:
’Good Gloſter, and good Deuill, were alike,
And both prepoſterous: therefore, not Good Lord.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Sirra, leaue vs to our ſelues, we muſt conferre.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: So ﬂies the wreakleſſe ſhepherd from ý Wolfe:
So ﬁrſt the harmleſſe Sheepe doth yeeld his Fleece,
And next his Throate, vnto the Butchers Knife.
What Scene of death hath Roſsius now to Ae?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Suſpition alwayes haunts the guilty minde,
The Theefe doth feare each buſh an Ofﬁcer,

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: The Bird that hath bin limed in a buſh,
With trembling wings miſdoubteth euery buſh;
And I the hapleſſe Male to one ſweet Bird,
Haue now the fatall Obie in my eye,
Where my poore yong was lim’d, was caught, and kill’d.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Why what a peeuiſh Foole was that of Creet,
That taught his Sonne the ofﬁce of a Fowle,
And yet for all his wings, the Foole was drown’d.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I Dedalus, my poore Boy Icarus,
Thy Father Minos, that deni’de our courſe,
The Sunne that ſear’d the wings of my ſweet Boy.
Thy Brother Edward, and thy Selfe, the Sea
Whoſe enuious Gulfe did ſwallow vp his life:
Ah, kill me with thy Weapon, not with words,
My breſt can better brooke thy Daggers point,
Then can my eares that Tragicke Hiſtory.
But wherefore doſt thou come? Is’t for my Life?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Think’ſt thou I am an Executioner?

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: A Perſecutor I am ſure thou art,
If murthering Innocents be Executing,
Why then thou art an Executioner.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thy Son I kill’d for his preſumption.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: Hadſt thou bin kill’d, when ﬁrſt ӳ didſt preſume,
Thou had’ſt not liu’d to kill a Sonne of mine:
And thus I propheſie, that many a thouſand,
Which now miſtruſt no parcell of my feare,
And many an old mans ſighe, and many a Widdowes,
And many an Orphans water-ſtanding-eye,
Men for their Sonnes, Wiues for their Husbands,
Orphans, for their Parents timeles death,
Shall rue the houre that euer thou was’t borne.
The Owle ſhriek’d at thy birth, an euill ſigne,
The Night-Crow cry’de, aboding luckleſſe time,
Dogs howl’d, and hiddeous Tempeſt ſhook down Trees:
The Rauen rook’d her on the Chimnies top,
And chatt’ring Pies in diſmall Diſcords ſung:
Thy Mother felt more then a Mothers paine,
And yet brought forth leſſe then a Mothers hope,
To wit, an indigeſted and deformed lumpe,
Not like the fruit of ſuch a goodly Tree.
Teeth had’ſt thou in thy head, when thou was’t borne,
To ſigniﬁe, thou cam’ſt to bite the world:
And if the reſt be true, which I haue heard,
Thou cam’ſt —

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ile heare no more:
Dye Prophet in thy ſpeech,
For this (among’ſt the reſt) was I ordain’d.

speech.speaker: Hen.
speech.line: I, and for much more ſlaughter aﬅer this,
O God forgiue my ſinnes, and pardon thee.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: What? will the aſpiring blood of Lancaſter
Sinke in the ground? I thought it would haue mounted.
See how my ſword weepes for the poore Kings death.
O may ſuch purple teares be alway ſhed
From thoſe that wiſh the downfall of our houſe.
If any ſparke of Life be yet remaining,
Downe, downe to hell, and ſay I ſent thee thither.
I that haue neyther pitty, loue, nor feare,
Indeed ’tis true that Henrie told me of:
For I haue oﬅen heard my Mother ſay,
I came into the world with my Legges forward.
Had I not reaſon (thinke ye) to make haſt,
And ſeeke their Ruine, that vſurp’d our Right?
The Midwife wonder’d, and the Women cri’de
O Ieſus bleſſe vs, he is borne with teeth,
And ſo I was, which plainly ſigniﬁed,
That I ſhould ſnarle, and bite, and play the dogge:
Then ſince the Heauens haue ſhap’d my Body ſo,
Let Hell make crook’d my Minde to anſwer it.
I haue no Brother, I am like no Brother:
And this word [Loue] which Gray-beards call Diuine,
Be reſident in men like one another,
And not in me: I am my ſelfe alone.
Clarence beware, thou keept’ſt me from the Light,
But I will ſort a pitchy day for thee:
For I will buzze abroad ſuch Propheſies,
That Edward ſhall be fearefull of his life,
And then to purge his feare, Ile be thy death.
King Henry, and the Prince his Son are gone,
Clarence thy turne is next, and then the reſt,
Counting my ſelfe but bad, till I be beſt.
Ile throw thy body in another roome,
And Triumph Henry, in thy day of Doome.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter King, Queene, Clarence, Richard, Haſtings, Nurſe, and Attendants.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Once more we ſit in Englands Royall Throne,
Re-purchac’d with the Blood of Enemies:
What valiant Fœ-men, like to Autumnes Corne,
Haue we mow’d downe in tops of all their pride?
Three Dukes of Somerſet, threefold Renowne,
For hardy and vndoubted Champions:
Two Cliffords, as the Father and the Sonne,
And two Northumberlands: two brauer men,
Ne’re ſpurr’d their Courſers at the Trumpets ſound.
With them, the two braue Beares, Warwick & Montague,
That in their Chaines fetter’d the Kingly Lyon,
And made the Forreſt tremble when they roar’d.
Thus haue we ſwept Suſpition from our Seate,
And made our Footſtoole of Security.
Come hither Beſſe, and let me kiſſe my Boy:
Yong Ned, for thee, thine Vnckles, and my ſelfe,
Haue in our Armors watcht the Winters night,
Went all afoote in Summers ſcalding heate,
That thou might’ſt repoſſeſſe the Crowne in peace,
And of our Labours thou ſhalt reape the gaine.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Ile blaſt his Harueſt, if your head were laid,
For yet I am not look’d on in the world.
This ſhoulder was ordain’d ſo thicke, to heaue,
And heaue it ſhall ſome waight, or breake my backe,
Worke thou the way, and that ſhalt execute.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Clarence and Gloſter, loue my louely Queene,
And kis your Princely Nephew Brothers both.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: The duty that I owe vnto your Maieſty,
I Seale vpon the lips of this ſweet Babe.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: Thanke Noble Clarence, worthy brother thanks.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And that I loue the tree frō whence ӳ ſprang’ſt:
Witneſſe the louing kiſſe I giue the Fruite,
To ſay the truth, ſo Iudas kiſt his maſter,
And cried all haile, when as he meant all harme.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Now am I ſeated as my ſoule delights,
Hauing my Countries peace, and Brothers loues.

speech.speaker: Cla.
speech.line: What will your Grace haue done with Margaret,
Reynard her Father, to the King of France
Hath pawn’d the Sicils and Ieruſalem,
And hither haue they ſent it for her ranſome.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Away with her, and waﬅ her hence to France:
And now what reſts, but that we ſpend the time
With ſtately Triumphes, mirthfull Comicke ſhewes,
Such as beﬁts the pleaſure of the Court.
Sound Drums and Trumpets, farwell ſowre annoy,
For heere I hope begins our laſting ioy.
